div.head: Act 1, Scene 1
div.stage: An apartment in the DUKE'S palace.
Enter DUKE, ESCALUS, Lords and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Escalus.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Of government the properties to unfold,
Would seem in me to affect speech and discourse;
Since I am put to know that your own science
Exceeds, in that, the lists of all advice
My strength can give you: then no more remains,
But that to your sufficiency…
…as your worth is able,
And let them work. The nature of our people,
Our city's institutions, and the terms
For common justice, y' are as pregnant in
As art and practice hath enriched any
That we remember. There is our commission,
From which we would not have you warp. Call hither,
I say, bid come before us Angelo. Exit an Attendant.
What figure of us think you he will bear?
For you must know, we have with special soul
Elected him our absence to supply,
Lent him our terror, dressed him with our love,
And given his deputation all the organs
Of our own power: what think you of it?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: If any in Vienna be of worth
To undergo such ample grace and honour,
It is Lord Angelo.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Look where he comes. Enter ANGELO.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Always obedient to your grace's will,
I come to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Angelo,
There is a kind of character in thy life,
That to the observer doth thy history
Fully unfold. Thyself and thy belongings
Are not thine own so proper as to waste
Thyself upon thy virtues, they on thee.
Heaven doth with us as we with torches do,
Not light them for themselves; for if our virtues
Did not go forth of us, 'twere all alike
As if we had them not. Spirits are not finely touched
But to fine issues, nor Nature never lends
The smallest scruple of her excellence
But, like a thrifty goddess, she determines
Herself the glory of a creditor,
Both thanks and use. But I do bend my speech
To one that can my part in him advertise;
Hold therefore, Angelo: —
In our remove be thou at full ourself;
Mortality and mercy in Vienna
Live in thy tongue and heart: old Escalus,
Though first in question, is thy secondary.
Take thy commission.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Now, good my lord,
Let there be some more test made of my metal,
Before so noble and so great a figure
Be stamped upon it.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: No more evasion:
We have with a leavened and prepared choice
Proceeded to you; therefore take your honours.
Our haste from hence is of so quick condition
That it prefers itself and leaves unquestioned
Matters of needful value. We shall write to you,
As time and our concernings shall importune,
How it goes with us, and do look to know
What doth befall you here. So, fare you well:
To the hopeful execution do I leave you
Of your commissions.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Yet give leave, my lord,
That we may bring you something on the way.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: My haste may not admit it;
Nor need you, on mine honour, have to do
With any scruple; your scope is as mine own,
So to enforce or qualify the laws
As to your soul seems good. Give me your hand:
I'll privily away. I love the people,
But do not like to stage me to their eyes:
Though it do well, I do not relish well
Their loud applause and Aves vehement;
Nor do I think the man of safe discretion
That does affect it. Once more, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: The heavens give safety to your purposes!

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: Lead forth and bring you back in happiness!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: I thank you. Fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: I shall desire you, sir, to give me leave
To have free speech with you; and it concerns me
To look into the bottom of my place:
A power I have, but of what strength and nature
I am not yet instructed.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: 'Tis so with me. Let us withdraw together,
And we may soon our satisfaction have
Touching that point.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: I'll wait upon your honour. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: If the duke with the other dukes come not to
composition with the King of Hungary, why then all the
dukes fall upon the king.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: Heaven grant us its peace, but not the King of
Hungary's!

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: Amen.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Thou concludest like the sanctimonious pirate,
that went to sea with the Ten Commandments, but
scraped one out of the table.

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: “Thou shalt not steal”?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Ay, that he razed.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: Why, 'twas a commandment to command the captain
and all the rest from their functions: they put
forth to steal. There's not a soldier of us all,
that, in the thanksgiving before meat, do relish the
petition well that prays for peace.

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: I never heard any soldier dislike it.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: I believe thee; for I think thou never wast where
grace was said.

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: No? a dozen times at least.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: What, in metre?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: In any proportion or in any language.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: I think, or in any religion.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Ay, why not? Grace is grace, despite of all
controversy: as for example, thou thyself art a wicked
villain, despite of all grace.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: Well, there went but a pair of shears between us.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: I grant; as there may between the lists and the
velvet. Thou art the list.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: And thou the velvet: thou art good velvet; thou'rt
a threepiled piece, I warrant thee: I had as lief
be a list of an English kersey as be piled, as
thou art piled, for a French velvet. Do I speak
feelingly now?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: I think thou dost; and, indeed, with most painful
feeling of thy speech: I will, out of thine own
confession, learn to begin thy health; but, whilst I
live, forget to drink after thee.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: I think I have done myself wrong, have I not?

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: Yes, that thou hast, whether thou art tainted or free.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Behold, behold, where Madam Mitigation comes! I
have purchased as many diseases under her roof as come
to —

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: To what, I pray?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Judge.

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: To three thousand dolours a year.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: Ay, and more.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: A French crown more.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: Thou art always figuring diseases in me; but thou art
full of error; I am sound.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Nay, not as one would say, healthy; but so sound
as things that are hollow: thy bones are hollow;
impiety has made a feast of thee.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: How now! which of your hips has the most profound
sciatica?

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: Well, well; there's one yonder arrested and
carried to prison was worth five thousand of you all.

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: Who's that, I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: Marry, sir, that's Claudio, Signior Claudio.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: Claudio to prison? 'tis not so.

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: Nay, but I know 'tis so: I saw him arrested, saw
him carried away; and, which is more, within these
three days his head to be chopped off.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: But, after all this fooling, I would not have it so.
Art thou sure of this?

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: I am too sure of it: and it is for getting Madam
Julietta with child.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Believe me, this may be: he promised to meet me
two hours since, and he was ever precise in
promise-keeping.

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: Besides, you know, it draws something near to the
speech we had to such a purpose.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: But, most of all, agreeing with the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Away! let's go learn the truth of it.

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: Thus, what with the war, what with the sweat,
what with the gallows and what with poverty, I
am custom-shrunk.
How now! what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Yonder man is carried to prison.

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: Well; what has he done?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: A woman.

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: But what's his offence?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Groping for trouts in a peculiar river.

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: What, is there a maid with child by him?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: No, but there's a woman with maid by him. You have not
heard of the proclamation, have you?

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: What proclamation, man?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: All houses in the suburbs of Vienna must be plucked
down?

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: And what shall become of those in the city?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: They shall stand for seed: they had gone down too, but
that a wise burgher put in for them.

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: But shall all our houses of resort in the suburbs be
pulled down?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: To the ground, mistress.

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: Why, here's a change indeed in the commonwealth! What
shall become of me?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Come; fear not you: good counsellors lack no
clients: though you change your place, you need
not change your trade; I'll be your tapster still.
Courage! there will be pity taken on you: you
that have worn your eyes almost out in the service,
you will be considered.

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: What's to do here, Thomas tapster? let's withdraw.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Here comes Signior Claudio, led by the provost to
prison; and there's Madam Juliet.
sp.stage: Enter PROVOST, CLAUDIO, JULIET, and Officers.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Fellow, why dost thou show me thus to the world?
Bear me to prison, where I am committed.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: I do it not in evil disposition,
But from Lord Angelo by special charge.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Thus can the demigod Authority
Make us pay down for our offence by weight
The words of heaven; on whom it will, it will;
On whom it will not, so; yet still 'tis just. Re-enter Lucio and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Why, how now, Claudio! whence comes this restraint?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: From too much liberty, my Lucio, liberty:
As surfeit is the father of much fast,
So every scope by the immoderate use
Turns to restraint. Our natures do pursue,
Like rats that ravin down their proper bane,
A thirsty evil; and when we drink we die.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: If I could speak so wisely under an arrest, I
would send for certain of my creditors: and yet,
to say the truth, I had as lief have the foppery
of freedom as the mortality of imprisonment. What's
thy offence, Claudio?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: What but to speak of would offend again.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: What, is't murder?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Lechery?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Call it so.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Away sir! you must go.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: One word, good friend. Lucio, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: A hundred, if they'll do you any good.
Is lechery so looked after?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Thus stands it with me: upon a true contract
I got possession of Julietta's bed:
You know the lady; she is fast my wife,
Save that we do the denunciation lack
Of outward order: this we came not to,
Only for propagation of a dower
Remaining in the coffer of her friends,
From whom we thought it meet to hide our love
Till time had made them for us. But it chances
The stealth of our most mutual entertainment
With character too gross is writ on Juliet.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: With child, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Unhappily, even so.
And the new deputy now for the duke —
Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newness,
Or whether that the body public be
A horse whereon the governor doth ride,
Who, newly in the seat, that it may know
He can command, lets it straight feel the spur;
Whether the tyranny be in his place,
Or in his eminence that fills it up,
I stagger in: — but this new governor
Awakes me all the enrolled penalties
Which have, like unscoured armour, hung by the wall
So long that nineteen zodiacs have gone round
And none of them been worn; and, for a name,
Now puts the drowsy and neglected act
Freshly on me: 'tis surely for a name.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: I warrant it is: and thy head stands so tickle
on thy shoulders that a milkmaid, if she be in
love, may sigh it off. Send after the duke and appeal
to him.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: I have done so, but he's not to be found.
I prithee, Lucio, do me this kind service:
This day my sister should the cloister enter
And there receive her approbation:
Acquaint her with the danger of my state;
Implore her, in my voice, that she make friends
To the strict deputy; bid herself assay him:
I have great hope in that; for in her youth
There is a prone and speechless dialect,
Such as move men; beside, she hath prosperous art
When she will play with reason and discourse,
And well she can persuade.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: I pray she may; as well for the encouragement of
the like, which else would stand under grievous
imposition, as for the enjoying of thy life, who
I would be sorry should be thus foolishly lost at a
game of tick-tack. I'll to her.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: I thank you, good friend Lucio.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Within two hours.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Come, officer, away! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: No, holy father; throw away that thought;
Believe not that the dribbling dart of love
Can pierce a complete bosom. Why I desire thee
To give me secret harbour, hath a purpose
More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends
Of burning youth.

sp.speaker: Thomas
sp.l: May your grace speak of it?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: My holy sir, none better knows than you
How I have ever loved the life removed
And held in idle price to haunt assemblies
Where youth, and cost, witless bravery keeps.
I have delivered to Lord Angelo,
A man of stricture and firm abstinence,
My absolute power and place here in Vienna,
And he supposes me travelled to Poland;
For so I have strewed it in the common ear,
And so it is received. Now, pious sir,
You will demand of me why I do this?

sp.speaker: Thomas
sp.l: Gladly, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: We have strict statutes and most biting laws,
The needful bits and curbs to headstrong weeds,
Which for this fourteen years we have let slip;
Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave,
That goes not out to prey. Now, as fond fathers,
Having bound up the threatening twigs of birch,
Only to stick it in their children's sight
For terror, not to use, in time the rod
Becomes more mocked than feared; so our decrees,
Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead;
And liberty plucks justice by the nose;
The baby beats the nurse, and quite athwart
Goes all decorum.

sp.speaker: Thomas
sp.l: It rested in your grace
To unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased:
And it in you more dreadful would have seemed
Than in Lord Angelo.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: I do fear, too dreadful:
Sith 'twas my fault to give the people scope,
'Twould be my tyranny to strike and gall them
For what I bid them do: for we bid this be done,
When evil deeds have their permissive pass
And not the punishment. Therefore indeed, my father,
I have on Angelo imposed the office;
Who may, in the ambush of my name, strike home,
And yet my nature never in the fight
To do in slander. And to behold his sway,
I will, as 'twere a brother of your order,
Visit both prince and people: therefore, I prithee,
Supply me with the habit and instruct me
How I may formally in person bear
Like a true friar. Moe reasons for this action
At our more leisure shall I render you;
Only, this one: Lord Angelo is precise;
Stands at a guard with envy; scarce confesses
That his blood flows, or that his appetite
Is more to bread than stone: hence shall we see,
If power change purpose, what our seemers be. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: And have you nuns no farther privileges?

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.l: Are not these large enough?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Yes, truly: I speak not as desiring more;
But rather wishing a more strict restraint
Upon the sisterhood, the votarists of Saint Clare.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Ho! Peace be in this place!

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Who's that which calls?

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.l: It is a man's voice. Gentle Isabella,
Turn you the key, and know his business of him;
You may, I may not; you are yet unsworn.
When you have vowed, you must not speak with men
But in the presence of the prioress:
Then, if you speak, you must not show your face,
Or, if you show your face, you must not speak.
He calls again; I pray you, answer him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Peace and prosperity! Who is't that calls? Enter Lucio.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Hail, virgin, if you be, as those cheek-roses
Proclaim you are no less! Can you so stead me
As bring me to the sight of Isabella,
A novice of this place and the fair sister
To her unhappy brother Claudio?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Why “her unhappy brother”? let me ask,
The rather for I now must make you know
I am that Isabella and his sister.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Gentle and fair, your brother kindly greets you:
Not to be weary with you, he's in prison.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Woe me! for what?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: For that which, if myself might be his judge,
He should receive his punishment in thanks:
He hath got his friend with child.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Sir, make me not your story.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: 'Tis true.
I would not — though 'tis my familiar sin
With maids to seem the lapwing and to jest,
Tongue far from heart — play with all virgins so:
I hold you as a thing enskied and sainted,
By your renouncement an immortal spirit,
And to be talked with in sincerity,
As with a saint.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: You do blaspheme the good in mocking me.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Do not believe it. Fewness and truth, 'tis thus:
Your brother and his lover have embraced:
As those that feed grow full as blossoming time
That from the seedness the bare fallow brings
To teeming foison, even so her plenteous womb
Expresseth his full tilth and husbandry.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Some one with child by him? My cousin Juliet?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Is she your cousin?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Adoptedly; as school-maids change their names
By vain though apt affection.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: She it is.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, let him marry her.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: This is the point.
The duke is very strangely gone from hence;
Bore many gentlemen, myself being one,
In hand and hope of action: but we do learn
By those that know the very nerves of state,
His givings-out were of an infinite distance
From his true-meant design. Upon his place,
And with full line of his authority,
Governs Lord Angelo; a man whose blood
Is very snow-broth; one who never feels
The wanton stings and motions of the sense,
But doth rebate and blunt his natural edge
With profits of the mind, study and fast.
He — to give fear to use and liberty,
Which have for long run by the hideous law,
As mice by lions — hath picked out an act,
Under whose heavy sense your brother's life
Falls into forfeit: he arrests him on it;
And follows close the rigour of the statute,
To make him an example. All hope is gone,
Unless you have the grace by your fair prayer
To soften Angelo: and that's my pith of business
'Twixt you and your poor brother.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Doth he so seek his life?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: He's censured him
Already; and, as I hear, the provost hath
A warrant for's execution.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Alas! What poor ability's in me
To do him good?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Assay the power you have.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: My power? Alas, I doubt —

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Our doubts are traitors
And makes us lose the good we oft might win
By fearing to attempt. Go to Lord Angelo,
And let him learn to know, when maidens sue,
Men give like gods; but when they weep and kneel,
All their petitions are as freely theirs
As they themselves would owe them.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I'll see what I can do.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: But speedily.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I will about it straight;
No longer staying but to give the mother
Notice of my affair. I humbly thank you:
Commend me to my brother: soon at night
I'll send him certain word of my success.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: I take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Good sir, adieu. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter ANGELO, ESCALUS, and a Justice, Provost, Officers, and other Attendants, behind.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: We must not make a scarecrow of the law,
Setting it up to fear the birds of prey,
And let it keep one shape, till custom make it
Their perch and not their terror.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: Ay, but yet
Let us be keen, and rather cut a little,
Than fall, and bruise to death. Alas, this gentleman,
Whom I would save, had a most noble father
Let but your honour know,
Whom I believe to be most strait in virtue,
That, in the working of your own affections,
Had time cohered with place or place with wishing,
Or that the resolute acting of your blood
Could have attained the effect of your own purpose,
Whether you had not sometime in your life
Erred in this point which now you censure him,
And pulled the law upon you.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: 'Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus,
Another thing to fall. I not deny,
The jury, passing on the prisoner's life,
May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two
Guiltier than him they try. What's open made to justice,
That justice seizes: what knows the laws
That thieves do pass on thieves? 'Tis very pregnant,
The jewel that we find, we stoop and take't
Because we see it; but what we do not see
We tread upon, and never think of it.
You may not so extenuate his offence
For I have had such faults; but rather tell me,
When I, that censure him, do so offend,
Let mine own judgement pattern out my death,
And nothing come in partial. Sir, he must die.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: Be it as your wisdom will.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Where is the provost?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Here, if it like your honour.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: See that Claudio
Be executed by nine to-morrow morning:
Bring him his confessor, let him be prepared;
For that's the utmost of his pilgrimage. Exit Provost.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: Well, heaven forgive him! and forgive us all!
Some rise by sin, and some by virtue fall:
Some run from brakes of ice, and answer none:
And some condemned for a fault alone. Enter ELBOW, and Officers with FROTH and POMPEY.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Come, bring them away: if these be good people
in a commonweal that do nothing but use their
abuses in common houses, I know no law: bring them
away.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: How now, sir! What's your name? and what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: If it please your honour, I am the poor duke's
constable, and my name is Elbow: I do lean upon
justice, sir, and do bring in here before your good
honour two notorious benefactors.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: Benefactors? Well; what benefactors are they? are they
not malefactors?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: If it please your honour, I know not well what
they are: but precise villains they are, that I
am sure of; and void of all profanation in the world
that good Christians ought to have.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: This comes off well; here's a wise officer.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: Go to: what quality are they of? Elbow is your name?
why dost thou not speak, Elbow?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: He cannot, sir; he's out at elbow.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: He, sir! a tapster, sir; parcel-bawd; one that
serves a bad woman; whose house, sir, was, as
they say, plucked down in the suburbs; and now
she professes a hot-house, which, I think, is a very
ill house too.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: My wife, sir, whom I detest before heaven and your
honour, —

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: How? thy wife?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Ay, sir; whom, I thank heaven, is an honest woman, —

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Dost thou detest her therefore?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: I say, sir, I will detest myself also, as well
as she, that this house, if it be not a bawd's
house, it is pity of her life, for it is a naughty
house.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: How dost thou know that, constable?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Marry, sir, by my wife; who, if she had been a
woman cardinally given, might have been accused
in fornication, adultery, and all uncleanliness there.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: By the woman's means?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Ay, sir, by Mistress Overdone's means: but as she spit
in his face, so she defied him.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Sir, if it please your honour, this is not so.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Prove it before these varlets here, thou honourable
man; prove it.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Do you hear how he misplaces?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Sir, she came in great with child; and longing,
saving your honours' reverence, for stewed prunes;
sir, we had but two in the house, which at that
very distant time stood, as it were, in a
fruit-dish, a dish of some threepence; your
honours have seen such dishes; they are not China
dishes, but very good dishes, —

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Go to, go to: no matter for the dish, sir.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: No, indeed, sir, not of a pin; you are therein
in the right: but to the point. As I say, this
Mistress Elbow, being, as I say, with child, and
being great-bellied, and longing, as I said, for
prunes; and having but two in the dish, as I
said, Master Froth here, this very man, having
eaten the rest, as I said, and, as I say, paying
for them very honestly; for, as you know, Master
Froth, I could not give you threepence again.

sp.speaker: Froth
sp.ab: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Very well; you being then, if you be remembered,
cracking the stones of the foresaid prunes, —

sp.speaker: Froth
sp.ab: Ay, so I did indeed.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Why, very well; I telling you then, if you be
remembered, that such a one and such a one were
past cure of the thing you wot of, unless they kept
very good diet, as I told you, —

sp.speaker: Froth
sp.ab: All this is true.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Why, very well, then, —

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Come, you are a tedious fool: to the purpose.
What was done to Elbow's wife, that he hath cause to
complain of? Come me to what was done to her.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Sir, your honour cannot come to that yet.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: No, sir, nor I mean it not.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Sir, but you shall come to it, by your honour's
leave. And, I beseech you, look into Master Froth
here, sir; a man of fourscore pound a year; whose
father died at Hallowmas: was't not at Hallowmas,
Master Froth?

sp.speaker: Froth
sp.ab: All-hallond eve.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Why, very well; I hope here be truths. He, sir,
sitting, as I say, in a lower chair, sir; 'twas
in the Bunch of Grapes, where indeed you have a
delight to sit, have you not?

sp.speaker: Froth
sp.ab: I have so; because it is an open room and good for
winter.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Why, very well, then; I hope here be truths.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: This will last out a night in Russia,
When nights are longest there: I'll take my leave,
And leave you to the hearing of the cause;
Hoping you'll find good cause to whip them all.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: I think no less. Good morrow to your lordship. Exit Angelo.
sp.ab: Now. sir come on: what was done to Elbow's wife, once
more?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Once, sir? there was nothing done to her once.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: I beseech you, sir, ask him what this man did to my
wife.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: I beseech your honour, ask me.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Well, sir; what did this gentleman to her?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: I beseech you, sir, look in this gentleman's
face. Good Master Froth, look upon his honour;
'tis for a good purpose. Doth your honour mark his
face?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Ay, sir, very well.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Nay, I beseech you, mark it well.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Well, I do so,

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Doth your honour see any harm in his face?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Why, no.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: I'll be supposed upon a book, his face is the
worst thing about him. Good, then; if his face
be the worst thing about him, how could Master
Froth do the constable's wife any harm? I would know
that of your honour.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: He's in the right. Constable, what say you to it?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: First, and it like you, the house is a respected
house; next, this is a respected fellow; and his
mistress is a respected woman.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: By this hand, sir, his wife is a more respected person
than any of us all.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Varlet, thou liest; thou liest, wicked varlet!
the time is yet to come that she was ever respected
with man, woman, or child.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Sir, she was respected with him before he married with
her.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Which is the wiser here? Justice or Iniquity? Is this
true?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: O thou caitiff! O thou varlet! O thou wicked
Hannibal! I respected with her before I was
married to her! If ever I was respected with her,
or she with me, let not your worship think me
the poor duke's officer. Prove this. thou wicked
Hannibal, or I'll have mine action of battery on thee.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: If he took you a box o' the ear, you might have your
action of slander too.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Marry, I thank your good worship for it. What
is't your worship's pleasure I shall do with this
wicked caitiff?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Truly, officer, because he hath some offences in
him that thou wouldst discover if thou couldst
let him continue in his courses till thou knowest what
they are.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Marry, I thank your worship for it. Thou seest,
thou wicked varlet, now, what's come upon thee:
thou art to continue now, thou varlet; thou art to
continue.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Where were you born, friend?

sp.speaker: Froth
sp.ab: Here in Vienna, sir.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Are you of fourscore pounds a year?

sp.speaker: Froth
sp.ab: Yes, and't please you, sir.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: So. What trade are you of, sir?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: A tapster; a poor widow's tapster.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Your mistress' name?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Mistress Overdone.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Hath she had any more than one husband?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Nine, sir; Overdone by the last.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Nine! Come hither to me, Master Froth. Master
Froth, I would not have you acquainted with
tapsters: they will draw you, Master Froth, and
you will hang them. Get you gone, and let me hear no
more of you.

sp.speaker: Froth
sp.ab: I thank your worship. For mine own part, I never come
into any room in a tap-house, but I am drawn in.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Well, no more of it, Master Froth: farewell.
Come you hither to me, Master tapster. What's your
name, Master tapster?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Pompey.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: What else?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Bum, sir.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Troth, and your bum is the greatest thing about
you; so that in the beastliest sense you are
Pompey the Great. Pompey, you are partly a bawd,
Pompey, howsoever you colour it in being a tapster,
are you not? Come, tell me true: it shall, be the
better for you.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Truly, sir, I am a poor fellow that would live.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: How would you live, Pompey? by being a bawd? What
do you think of the trade, Pompey? is it a lawful
trade?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: If the law would allow it, sir.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: But the law will not allow it, Pompey; nor it shall
not be allowed in Vienna.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Does your worship mean to geld and splay all the youth
of the city?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: No, Pompey.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Truly, sir, in my poor opinion, they will to't
then. If your worship will take order for the
drabs and the knaves, you need not to fear the bawds.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: There is pretty orders beginning, I can tell you: it
is but heading and hanging.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: If you head and hang all that offend that way
but for ten year together, you'll be glad to give
out a commission for more heads: if this law hold
in Vienna ten year, I'll rent the fairest house
in it after threepence a bay: if you live to see this
come to pass, say Pompey told you so.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Thank you, good Pompey; and, in requital of your
prophecy, hark you, I advise you, let me not find
you before me again upon any complaint whatsoever;
no, not for dwelling where you do: if I do,
Pompey, I shall beat you to your tent, and prove
a shrewd Caesar to you; in plain-dealing, Pompey,
I shall have you whipped: so, for this time, Pompey,
fare you well.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: I thank your worship for your good counsel:
but I shall follow it as the flesh and fortune shall
better determine.
sp.l: Whip me? No, no; let carman whip his jade:
The valiant heart's not whipped out of his trade. Exit.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Come hither to me, Master Elbow; come hither,
Master constable. How long have you been in this place
of constable?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Seven year and a half, sir.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: I thought, by the readiness in the office, you
had continued in it some time. You say, seven years
together?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: And a half, sir.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Alas, it hath been great pains to you. They do
you wrong to put you so oft upon't: are there not men
in your ward sufficient to serve it?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Faith, sir, few of any wit in such matters: as
they are chosen, they are glad to choose me for
them; I do it for some piece of money, and go through
with all.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Look you bring me in the names of some six or seven,
the most sufficient of your parish.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: To your worship's house, sir?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: To my house. Fare you well.
What's o'clock, think you?

sp.speaker: A Justice
sp.ab: Eleven, sir.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: I pray you home to dinner with me.

sp.speaker: A Justice
sp.ab: I humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: It grieves me for the death of Claudio;
But there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: A Justice
sp.l: Lord Angelo is severe.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: It is but needful:
Mercy is not itself, that oft looks so;
Pardon is still the nurse of second woe:
But yet, — poor Claudio! There is no remedy.
Come, sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He's hearing of a cause; he will come straight:
I'll tell him of you.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Pray you, do. Exit Servant. I'll know
His pleasure; may be he will relent. Alas,
He hath but as offended in a dream!
All sects, all ages smack of this vice; and he
To die for't! Enter ANGELO.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Now, what's the matter, provost?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Is it your will Claudio shall die to-morrow?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Did not I tell thee yea? hadst thou not order?
Why dost thou ask again?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Lest I might be too rash:
Under your good correction. I have seen,
When, after execution, judgement hath
Repented o'er his doom.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Go to; let that be mine:
Do you your office. or give up your place,
And you shall well be spared.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: I crave your honour's pardon.
What shall be done, sir, with the groaning Juliet?
She's very near her hour.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Dispose of her
To some more fitter place, and that with speed. Re-enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here is the sister of the man condemned
Desires access to you.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Hath he a sister?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Ay, my good lord; a very virtuous maid,
And to be shortly of a sisterhood,
If not already.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Well, let her be admitted. Exit Servant.
See you the fornicatress be removed:
Let her have needful, but not lavish, means;
There shall be order for't. Enter ISABELLA and LUCIO.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: 'Save your honour!

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Stay a little while. To Isab.
Y' are welcome: what's your will?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I am a woeful suitor to your honour,
Please but your honour hear me.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Well; what's your suit?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: There is a vice that most I do abhor,
And most desire should meet the blow of justice;
For which I would not plead, but that I must;
For which I must not plead, but that I am
At war 'twixt will and will not.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Well; the matter?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I have a brother is condemned to die:
I do beseech you, let it be his fault,
And not my brother.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Heaven give thee moving graces!

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Condemn the fault, and not the actor of it?
Why, every fault's condemned ere it be done:
Mine were the very cipher of a function,
To fine the faults whose fine stands in record,
And let go by the actor.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O just but severe law!
I had a brother, then. Heaven keep your honour!

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Give't not o'er so: to him again, entreat him;
Kneel down before him, hang upon his gown:
You are too cold; if you should need a pin,
You could not with more tame a tongue desire it:
To him, I say!

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Must he needs die?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Maiden, no remedy.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Yes; I do think that you might pardon him,
And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I will not do't.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: But can you, if you would?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Look, what I will not, that I cannot do.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: But might you do't, and do the world no wrong,
If so your heart were touched with that remorse
As mine is to him?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: He's sentenced; 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: You are too cold.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Too late? why, no; I, that do speak a word,
May call it again. Well, believe this,
No ceremony that to great ones 'longs,
Not the king's crown, nor the deputed sword,
The marshal's truncheon, nor the judge's robe,
Become them with one half so good a grace
As mercy does.
If he had been as you and you as he,
You would have slipped like him; but he, like you,
Would not have been so stern.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Pray you, be gone.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I would to heaven I had your potency,
And you were Isabel! should it then be thus?
No; I would tell what 'twere to be a judge,
And what a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Ay, touch him; there's the vein.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Your brother is a forfeit of the law,
And you but waste your words.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Alas, alas!
Why, all the souls that were were forfeit once;
And He that might the vantage best have took
Found out the remedy. How would you be,
If He, which is the top of judgement, should
But judge you as you are? O, think on that;
And mercy then will breathe within your lips
Like man new made.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Be you content, fair maid;
It is the law, not I condemn your brother:
Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son,
It should be thus with him: he must die to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: To-morrow! O, that's sudden! Spare him, spare him!
He's not prepared for death. Even for our kitchens
We kill the fowl of season: shall we serve heaven
With less respect than we do minister
To our gross selves? Good, good my lord, bethink you;
Who is it that hath died for this offence?
There's many have committed it.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Ay, well said.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: The law hath not been dead, though it hath slept:
Those many had not dared to do that evil,
If the first that did the edict infringe
Had answered for his deed: now 'tis awake,
Takes note of what is done; and, like a prophet,
Looks in a glass, that shows what future evils,
Either now, or by remissness new conceived,
And so in progress to be hatched and born,
Are now to have no successive degrees,
But, ere they live, to end.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Yet show some pity.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I show it most of all when I show justice;
For then I pity those I do not know,
Which a dismissed offence would after gall;
And do him right that, answering one foul wrong,
Lives not to act another. Be satisfied;
Your brother dies to-morrow; be content.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: So you must be the first that gives this sentence,
And he, that suffers. O, it is excellent
To have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous
To use it like a giant.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: That's well said.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Could great men thunder
As Jove himself does, Jove would ne'er be quiet,
For every pelting, petty officer
Would use his heaven for thunder;
Nothing but thunder! Merciful Heaven,
Thou rather with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt
Splits the unwedgeable and gnarled oak
Than the soft myrtle: but man, proud man,
Dressed in a little brief authority,
Most ignorant of what he's most assured,
His glassy essence, like an angry ape,
Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven
As makes the angels weep; who, with our spleens,
Would all themselves laugh mortal.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: O, to him, to him, wench! he will relent;
He's coming; I perceive't.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Pray heaven she win him!

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: We cannot weigh our brother with ourself:
Great men may jest with saints; 'tis wit in them,
But in the less foul profanation.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Thou'rt i' the right, girl; more o' that.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: That in the captain's but a choleric word,
Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Art avised o' that? more on't.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Why do you put these sayings upon me?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Because authority, though it err like others,
Hath yet a kind of medicine in itself,
That skins the vice o' the top. Go to your bosom;
Knock there, and ask your heart what it doth know
That's like my brother's fault: if it confess
A natural guiltiness such as is his,
Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue
Against my brother's life.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: She speaks, and 'tis
Such sense, that my sense breeds with it. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Gentle my lord, turn back.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I will bethink me: come again to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Hark how I'll bribe you: good my lord, turn back.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: How! bribe me?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Ay, with such gifts that heaven shall share with you.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: You had marred all else.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Not with fond shekels of the tested gold,
Or stones whose rate are either rich or poor
As fancy values them; but with true prayers
That shall be up at heaven and enter there
Ere sun-rise, prayers from preserved souls,
From fasting maids whose minds are dedicate
To nothing temporal.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Well; come to me to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Go to; 'tis well; away!

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Heaven keep your honour safe!

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Amen:
For I am that way going to temptation,
Where prayers cross.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: At what hour to-morrow
Shall I attend your lordship?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: At any time 'fore noon.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: 'Save your honour! Exeunt Isabella, Luclo, and Provost.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: From thee, even from thy virtue!
What's this, what's this? Is this her fault or mine,
The tempter or the tempted, who sins most?
Ha!
Not she; nor doth she tempt: but it is I
That, lying by the violet in the sun,
Do as the carrion does, not as the flower,
Corrupt with virtuous season. Can it be
That modesty may more betray our sense
Than woman's lightness? Having waste ground enough,
Shall we desire to raze the sanctuary
And pitch our evils there? O, fie, fie, fie!
What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo?
Dost thou desire her foully for those things
That make her good? O, let her brother live:
Thieves for their robbery have authority
When judges steal themselves. What, do I love her,
That I desire to hear her speak again,
And feast upon her eyes? What is't I dream on?
O cunning enemy, that, to catch a saint,
With saints dost bait thy hook! Most dangerous
Is that temptation that doth goad us on
To sin in loving virtue: never could the strumpet,
With all her double vigour, art and nature,
Once stir my temper; but this virtuous maid
Subdues me quite. Ever till now,
When men were fond, I smiled and wondered how. Exit.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter, severally, DUKE disguised as a friar, and PROVOST.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Hail to you, provost! so I think you are.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: I am the provost. What's your will, good friar?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Bound by my charity and my blest order,
I come to visit the afflicted spirits
Here in the prison. Do me the common right
To let me see them and to make me know
The nature of their crimes, that I may minister
To them accordingly.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: I would do more than that, if more were needful. Enter JULIET.
Look here comes one: a gentlewoman of mine,
Who, falling in the flaws of her own youth,
Hath blistered her report: she is with child;
And he that got it, sentenced; a young man
More fit to do another such offence
Than die for this.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: When must he die?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: As I do think, to-morrow,
I have provided for you: stay awhile, To Juliet.
And you shall be conducted.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?

sp.speaker: Juliet
sp.l: I do; and bear the shame most patiently.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience,
And try your penitence, if it be sound,
Or hollowly put on.

sp.speaker: Juliet
sp.l: I'll gladly learn.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Love you the man that wronged you?

sp.speaker: Juliet
sp.l: Yes, as I love the woman that wronged him.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: So then it seems your most offenceful act
Was mutually committed?

sp.speaker: Juliet
sp.l: Mutually.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Then was your sin of heavier kind than his.

sp.speaker: Juliet
sp.l: I do confess it, and repent it, father.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: 'Tis meet so, daughter: but lest you do repent,
As that the sin hath brought you to this shame,
Which sorrow is always toward ourselves, not heaven,
Showing we would not spare heaven as we love it,
But as we stand in fear, —

sp.speaker: Juliet
sp.l: I do repent me, as it is an evil,
And take the shame with joy.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: There rest.
Your partner, as I hear, must die to-morrow,
And I am going with instruction to him.
Grace go with you, Benedicite! Exit.

sp.speaker: Juliet
sp.l: Must die to-morrow! O injurious love,
That respites me a life, whose very comfort
Is still a dying horror!

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: 'Tis pity of him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: When I would pray and think, I think and pray
To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words;
Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue,
Anchors on Isabel: Heaven in my mouth,
As if I did but only chew his name;
And in my heart the strong and swelling evil
Of my conception. The state, whereon I studied,
Is like a good thing, being often read,
Grown sere and tedious; yea, my gravity,
Wherein — let no man hear me — I take pride,
Could I with boot change for an idle plume,
Which the air beats for vain. O place, O form,
How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit,
Wrench awe from fools and tie the wiser souls
To thy false seeming! Blood, thou art blood:
Let's write good angel on the devil's horn;
'Tis not the devil's crest. Enter a SERVANT. How now! who's there?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Teach her the way. Exit Serv.
O heavens!
Why does my blood thus muster to my heart,
Making both it unable for itself,
And dispossessing all my other parts
Of necessary fitness?
So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons;
Come all to help him, and so stop the air
By which he should revive: and even so
The general, subject to a well-wished king,
Quit their own part, and in obsequious fondness
Crowd to his presence, where their untaught love
Must needs appear offence. Enter ISABELLA. How now, fair maid?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I am come to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: That you might know it, would much better please me
Than to demand what 'tis. Your brother cannot live.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Even so. Heaven keep your honour!

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Yet may he live awhile; and, it may be,
As long as you or I: yet he must die.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Under your sentence?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Yea.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: When, I beseech you? that in his reprieve,
Longer or shorter, he may be so fitted
That his soul sicken not.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Ha! fie, these filthy vices! It were as good
To pardon him that hath from nature stolen
A man already made, as to remit
Their saucy sweetness that do coin heaven's image
In stamps that are forbid: 'tis all as easy
Falsely to take away a life true made
As to put metal in restrained means
To make a false one.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: 'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in earth.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Say you so? then I shall pose you quickly.
Which had you rather, that the most just law
Now took your brother's life; or, to redeem him,
Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness
As she that he hath stained?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Sir, believe this,
I had rather give my body than my soul.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I talk not of your soul: our compelled sins
Stand more for number than for accompt.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: How say you?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Nay, I'll not warrant that; for I can speak
Against the thing I say. Answer to this:
I, now the voice of the recorded law,
Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life:
Might there not be a charity in sin
To save this brother's life?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Please you to do't.
I'll take it as a peril to my soul,
It is no sin at all, but charity.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul,
Were equal poise of sin and charity.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: That I do beg his life if it be sin,
Heaven let me bear it! you granting of my suit,
If that be sin, I'll make it my morn-prayer
To have it added to the faults of mine,
And nothing of your answer.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Nay, but hear me.
Your sense pursues not mine: either you are ignorant,
Or seem so craftily; and that's not good.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Let me be ignorant, and in nothing good,
But graciously to know I am no better.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright
When it doth tax itself; as these black masks
Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder
Than beauty could, displayed. But mark me;
To be received plain, I'll speak more gross:
Your brother is to die.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: And his offence is so, as it appears,
Accountant to the law upon that pain.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Admit no other way to save his life, —
As I subscribe not that, nor any other,
But in the loss of question, — that you, his sister,
Finding yourself desired of such a person,
Whose credit with the judge, or own great place,
Could fetch your brother from the manacles
Of the all-binding law; and that there were
No earthly mean to save him, but that either
You must lay down the treasures of your body
To this supposed, or else to let him suffer,
What would you do?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: As much for my poor brother as myself:
That is, were I under the terms of death,
The impression of keen whips I'ld wear as rubies,
And strip myself to death, as to a bed
That longing have been sick for, ere I'ld yield
My body up to shame.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Then must your brother die.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: And 'twere the cheaper way:
Better it were a brother died at once,
Than that a sister, by redeeming him,
Should die forever.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Were not you then as cruel as the sentence
That you have slandered so?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Ignomy in ransom and free pardon
Are of two houses: lawful mercy
Is nothing kin to foul redemption.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: You seemed of late to make the law a tyrant;
And rather proved the sliding of your brother
A merriment than a vice.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, pardon me, my lord; it oft falls out,
To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean:
I something do excuse the thing I hate,
For his advantage that I dearly love,

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: We are all frail.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Else let my brother die,
If not a feodary, but only he
Owe and succeed thy weakness.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Nay, women are frail too.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Ay, as the glasses where they view themselves;
Which are as easy broke as they make forms.
Women! Help Heaven! men their creation mar
In profiting by them. Nay, call us ten times frail;
For we are soft as our complexions are,
And credulous to false prints.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I think it well:
And from this testimony of your own sex, —
Since I suppose we are made to be no stronger
Than faults may shake our frames, — let me be bold:
I do arrest your words. Be that you are,
That is, a woman; if you be more, you're none;
If you be one, as you are well expressed
By all external warrants, show it now,
By putting on the destined livery.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I have no tongue but one: gentle my lord,
Let me entreat you speak the former language.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Plainly conceive, I love you.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: My brother did love Juliet,
And you tell me that he shall die for't.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I know your virtue hath a license in't,
Which seems a little fouler than it is,
To pluck on others.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Believe me, on mine honour,
My words express my purpose.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Ha! little honour to be much believed,
And most pernicious purpose! Seeming, seeming!
I will proclaim thee, Angelo; look for't:
Sign me a present pardon for my brother,
Or with an outstretched throat I'll tell the world aloud
What man thou art.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Who will believe thee, Isabel?
My unsoiled name, the austereness of my life,
My vouch against you, and my place i' the state,
Will so your accusation overweigh,
That you shall stifle in your own report
And smell of calumny. I have begun,
And now I give my sensual race the rein:
Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite;
Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes,
That banish what they sue for; redeem thy brother
By yielding up thy body to my will;
Or else he must not only die the death,
But thy unkindness shall his death draw out
To lingering sufferance. Answer me to-morrow,
Or, by the affection that now guides me most,
I'll prove a tyrant to him. As for you,
Say what you can, my false o'erweighs your true. Exit.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: To whom should I complain? Did I tell this,
Who would believe me? O perilous mouths,
That bear in them one and the selfsame tongue,
Either of condemnation or approof;
Bidding the law make curtsy to their will;
Hooking both right and wrong to the appetite,
To follow as it draws! I'll to my brother:
Though he hath fall'n by prompture of the blood,
Yet hath he in him such a mind of honour,
That, had he twenty heads to tender down
On twenty bloody blocks, he'ld yield them up,
Before his sister should her body stoop
To such abhorred pollution.
Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die:
More than our brother is our chastity.
I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request,
And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest Exit

div.head: Act 3, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter DUKE disguised as before, CLAUDIO, and PROVOST.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: The miserable have no other medicine
But only hope:
I have hope to live, and am prepared to die,

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Be absolute for death; either death or life
Shall thereby be the sweeter. Reason thus with life:
If I do lose thee, I do lose a thing
That none but fools would keep: a breath thou art,
Servile to all the skyey influences,
That dost this habitation, where thou keep'st,
Hourly afflict: merely, thou art death's fool;
For him thou labour'st by thy flight to shun
And yet runn'st toward him still. Thou art not noble;
For all the accommodations that thou bear'st
Are nursed by baseness. Thou'rt by no means valiant;
For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork
Of a poor worm. Thy best of rest is sleep,
And that thou oft provokes; yet grossly fear'st
Thy death, which is no more. Thou art not thyself;
For thou exist'st on many a thousand grains
That issue out of dust. Happy thou art not;
For what thou hast not, still thou strivest to get,
And what thou hast, forget'st. Thou art not certain;
For thy complexion shifts to strange effects,
After the moon. If thou art rich, thou'rt poor;
For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows,
Thou bear'st thy heavy riches but a journey,
And death unloads thee. Friend hast thou none;
For thine own bowels, which do call thee sire,
The mere effusion of thy proper loins,
Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum,
For ending thee no sooner. Thou hast nor youth nor age,
But, as it were, an after-dinner's sleep,
Dreaming on both; for all thy blessed youth
Becomes as aged, and doth beg the alms
Of palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich,
Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty,
To make thy riches pleasant. What's yet in this
That bears the name of life? Yet in this life
Lie hid moe thousand deaths: yet death we fear,
That makes these odds all even.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: I humbly thank you.
To sue to live, I find I seek to die;
And seeking death, find life: let it come on.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: What, ho! Peace here; grace and good company!

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Who's there? come in: the wish deserves a welcome.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Dear sir, ere long I'll visit you again.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Most holy sir, I thank you. Enter ISABELLA.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: My business is a word or two with Claudio.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: And very welcome. Look, signior, here's your sister.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Provost, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: As many as you please.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Bring me to hear them speak, where I may be concealed. Exeunt Duke and Provost.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Now, sister, what's the comfort?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Why,
As all comforts are; most good, most good indeed.
Lord Angelo, having affairs to heaven,
Intends you for his swift ambassador,
Where you shall be an everlasting leiger:
Therefore your best appointment make with speed;
To-morrow you set on.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Is there no remedy?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: None, but such remedy as, to save a head,
To cleave a heart in twain.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: But is there any?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Yes, brother, you may live:
There is a devilish mercy in the judge,
If you'll implore it, that will free your life,
But fetter you till death.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Perpetual durance?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Ay, just; perpetual durance, a restraint,
Though all the world's vastidity you had,
To a determined scope.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: But in what nature?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: In such a one as, you consenting to't,
Would bark your honour from that trunk you bear,
And leave you naked.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Let me know the point.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, I do fear thee, Claudio; and I quake,
Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain,
And six or seven winters more respect
Than a perpetual honour. Darest thou die?
The sense of death is most in apprehension;
And the poor beetle, that we tread upon,
In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great
As when a giant dies.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Why give you me this shame?
Think you I can a resolution fetch
From flowery tenderness? If I must die,
I will encounter darkness as a bride,
And hug it in mine arms.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: There spake my brother; there my father's grave
Did utter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die:
Thou art too noble to conserve a life
In base appliances. This outward-sainted deputy,
Whose settled visage and deliberate word
Nips youth i' the head and follies doth enew
As falcon doth the fowl, is yet a devil;
His filth within being cast, he would appear
A pond as deep as hell.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: The prenzie Angelo!

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, 'tis the cunning livery of hell,
The damned'st body to invest and cover
In prenzie guards! Dost thou think, Claudio?
If I would yield him my virginity,
Thou mightst be freed.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: O heavens! it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Yes, he would give't thee, from this rank offence,
So to offend him still. This night's the time
That I should do what I abhor to name,
Or else thou diest to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Thou shalt not do't

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, were it but my life,
I'ld throw it down for your deliverance
As frankly as a pin.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Thanks, dear Isabel.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Be ready, Claudio, for your death to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Yes. Has he affections in him,
That thus can make him bite the law by the nose,
When he would force it? Sure, it is no sin;
Or of the deadly seven it is the least.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Which is the least?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: If it were damnable, he being so wise,
Why would he for the momentary trick
Be perdurably fined? O Isabel!

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: What says my brother?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Death is a fearful thing.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: And shamed life a hateful.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Ay, but to die, and go we know not where;
To lie in cold obstruction and to rot;
This sensible warm motion to become
A kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit
To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside
In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice;
To be imprisoned in the viewless winds,
And blown with restless violence round about
The pendent world; or to be worse than worst
Of those that lawless and incertain thought
Imagine howling: 'tis too horrible!
The weariest and most loathed worldly life
That age, ache, penury and imprisonment
Can lay on nature is a paradise
To what we fear of death.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Alas, alas!

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Sweet sister, let me live:
What sin you do to save a brother's life,
Nature dispenses with the deed so far
That it becomes a virtue.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O you beast!
O faithless coward! O dishonest wretch!
Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice?
Is't not a kind of incest, to take life
From thine own sister's shame? What should I think?
Heaven shield my mother played my father fair!
For such a warped slip of wilderness
Ne'er issued from his blood. Take my defiance!
Die, perish! Might but my bending down
Reprieve thee from thy fate, it should proceed:
I'll pray a thousand prayers for thy death,
No word to save thee.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Nay, hear me, Isabel.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, fie, fie, fie!
Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade.
Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd:
'Tis best that thou diest quickly.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: O hear me, Isabella! Re-enter DUKE.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Might you dispense with your leisure, I would by
and by have some speech with you: the satisfaction I
would require is likewise your own benefit.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.ab: I have no superfluous leisure; my stay must be
stolen out of other affairs; but I will attend you a
while.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Son, I have overheard what hath passed between
you and your sister. Angelo had never the purpose
to corrupt her; only he hath made an assay of
her virtue to practise his judgement with the
disposition of natures: she, having the truth of
honour in her, hath made him that gracious denial
which he is most glad to receive. I am confessor
to Angelo, and I know this to be true; therefore
prepare yourself to death: do not satisfy your
resolution with hopes that are fallible: to-morrow you
must die; go to your knees and make ready.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Let me ask my sister pardon. I am so out of love with
life that I will sue to be rid of it.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Hold you there: farewell.
Provost, a word with you!

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: What's your will, father?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: That now you are come, you will be gone. Leave
me awhile with the maid: my mind promises with my
habit no loss shall touch her by my company.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: In good time.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: The hand that hath made you fair hath made you
good: the goodness that is cheap in beauty makes
beauty brief in goodness; but grace, being the
soul of your complexion, shall keep the body of
it ever fair. The assault that Angelo hath made
to you, fortune hath conveyed to my understanding;
and, but that frailty hath examples for his
falling, I should wonder at Angelo. How will you
do to content this substitute, and to save your
brother?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.ab: I am now going to resolve him; I had rather my
brother die by the law than my son should be
unlawfully born. But, O, how much is the good
duke deceived in Angelo! If ever he return and
I can speak to him, I will open my lips in vain, or
discover his government.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: That shall not be much amiss: yet, as the matter
now stands, he will avoid your accusation; he
made trial of you only. Therefore fasten your
ear on my advisings: to the love I have in doing
good a remedy presents itself. I do make myself
believe that you may most uprighteously do a poor
wronged lady a merited benefit; redeem your
brother from the angry law; do no stain to your
own gracious person; and much please the absent
duke, if peradventure he shall ever return to have
hearing of this business.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.ab: Let me hear you speak farther. I have spirit to
do any thing that appears not foul in the truth of my
spirit.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Virtue is bold, and goodness never fearful. Have
you not heard speak of Mariana, the sister of
Frederick the great soldier who miscarried at sea?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.ab: I have heard of the lady, and good words went with her
name.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: She should this Angelo have married; was affianced
to her by oath, and the nuptial appointed: between
which time of the contract and limit of the
solemnity, her brother Frederick was wracked at
sea, having in that perished vessel the dowry of
his sister. But mark how heavily this befell to
the poor gentlewoman: there she lost a noble and
renowned brother, in his love toward her ever
most kind and natural; with him, the portion and
sinew of her fortune, her marriage-dowry; with
both, her combinate-husband, this well-seeming Angelo.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.ab: Can this be so? did Angelo so leave her?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Left her in her tears, and dried not one of them
with his comfort; swallowed his vows whole,
pretending in her discoveries of dishonour: in
few, bestowed her on her own lamentation, which
she yet wears for his sake; and he, a marble to her
tears, is washed with them, but relents not.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.ab: What a merit were it in death to take this poor
maid from the world! What corruption in this
life, that it will let this man live! But how out of
this can she avail?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: It is a rupture that you may easily heal: and
the cure of it not only saves your brother, but keeps
you from dishonour in doing it.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.ab: Show me how, good father.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance
of her first affection: his unjust unkindness,
that in all reason should have quenched her love,
hath, like an impediment in the current, made it
more violent and unruly. Go you to Angelo; answer
his requiring with a plausible obedience; agree
with his demands to the point; only refer yourself
to this advantage, first, that your stay with
him may not be long; that the time may have all
shadow and silence in it; and the place answer
to convenience. This being granted in course, —
and now follows all, — we shall advise this wronged
maid to stead up your appointment, go in your
place; if the encounter acknowledge itself
hereafter, it may compel him to her recompense:
and here, by this, is your brother saved, your
honour untainted, the poor Mariana advantaged,
and the corrupt deputy scaled. The maid will I
frame and make fit for his attempt. If you think
well to carry this as you may, the doubleness of
the benefit defends the deceit from reproof. What
think you of it?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.ab: The image of it gives me content already; and I trust
it will grow to a most prosperous perfection.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: It lies much in your holding up. Haste you speedily
to Angelo: if for this night he entreat you to
his bed, give him promise of satisfaction. I will
presently to Saint Luke's: there, at the moated
grange, resides this dejected Mariana. At that
place call upon me; and dispatch with Angelo, that it
may be quickly.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.ab: I thank you for this comfort. Fare you well, good
father.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter, on one side, DUKE disguised as before; on the other, ELBOW, and Officers with POMPEY.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but that you
will needs buy and sell men and women like beasts,
we shall have all the world drink brown and white
bastard.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: O heavens! what stuff is here?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: 'Twas never merry world since, of two usuries,
the merriest was put down, and the worser allowed
by order of law a furred gown to keep him warm;
and furred with fox and lambskins too, to signify,
that craft, being richer than innocency, stands for
the facing.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Come your way, sir. Bless you, good father friar.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: And you, good brother father. What offence hath this
man made you, sir?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Marry, sir, he hath offended the law: and, sir,
we take him to be a thief too, sir; for we have
found upon him, sir, a strange picklock, which we have
sent to the deputy.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Fie, sirrah! a bawd, a wicked bawd!
The evil that thou causest to be done,
That is thy means to live. Do thou but think
What 'tis to cram a maw or clothe a back
From such a filthy vice: say to thyself,
From their abominable and beastly touches
I drink, I eat, array myself, and live.
Canst thou believe thy living is a life,
So stinkingly depending? Go mend, go mend.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Indeed, it does stink in some sort, sir; but yet, sir,
I would prove —

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Nay, if the devil have given thee proofs for sin,
Thou wilt prove his. Take him to prison, officer:
Correction and instruction must both work
Ere this rude beast will profit.

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: He must before the deputy, sir; he has given him
warning: the deputy cannot abide a whoremaster:
if he be a whoremonger, and comes before him, he were
as good go a mile on his errand.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: That we were all, as some would seem to be,
From our faults as faults from seeming, free!

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: His neck will come to your waist, — a cord, sir.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: I spy comfort; I cry bail. Here's a gentleman and a
friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: How now, noble Pompey! What, at the wheels of
Caesar? art thou led in triumph? What, is there
none of Pygmalion's images, newly made woman, to
be had now, for putting the hand in the pocket
and extracting it clutched? What reply, ha? What
sayest thou to this tune, matter and method? Is't
not drowned i' the last rain, ha? What sayest
thou, Trot? Is the world as it was, man? Which
is the way? Is it sad, and few words? or how? The
trick of it?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Still thus, and thus; still worse!

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: How doth my dear morsel, thy mistress? Procures she
still, ha?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Troth, sir, she hath eaten up all her beef, and she is
herself in the tub.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Why, 'tis good; it is the right of it; it must
be so: ever your fresh whore and your powdered
bawd: an unshunned consequence; it must be so. Art
going to prison, Pompey?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Yes, faith, sir.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Why, 'tis not amiss, Pompey: Farewell: go say I sent
thee thither. For debt, Pompey, or how?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: For being a bawd, for being a bawd.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Well, then, imprison him: if imprisonment be the
due of a bawd, why, 'tis his right: bawd is he
doubtless, and of antiquity too; bawd-born.
Farewell, good Pompey. Commend me to the prison,
Pompey: you will turn good husband now, Pompey; you
will keep the house.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: I hope, sir, your good worship will be my bail.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: No, indeed, will I not, Pompey; it is not the
wear. I will pray, Pompey, to increase your
bondage: if you take it not patiently, why, your
mettle is the more. Adieu, trusty Pompey, Bless you,
friar.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: And you.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Come your ways, sir; come.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: You will not bail me, then, sir?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Then, Pompey, nor now. What news abroad, friar? what
news?

sp.speaker: Elbow
sp.ab: Come your ways, sir; come.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Go to kennel, Pompey; go.
What news, friar, of the duke?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: I know none. Can you tell me of any?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia; other some,
he is in Rome: but where is he, think you?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: I know not where; but wheresoever, I wish him well.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: It was a mad fantastical trick of him to steal
from the state, and usurp the beggary he was
never born to. Lord Angelo dukes it well in his
absence; he puts transgression to't.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: He does well in't.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: A little more lenity to lechery would do no harm in
him: something too crabbed that way, friar.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: It is too general a vice, and severity must cure it.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Yes, in good sooth, the vice is of a great kindred;
it is well allied: but it is impossible to extirp
it quite, friar, till eating and drinking be put
down. They say this Angelo was not made by man
and woman after this downright way of creation: is it
true, think you?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: How should he be made, then?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Some report a sea-maid spawned him; some, that
he was begot between two stock-fishes. But it is
certain that when he makes water his urine is
congealed ice; that I know to be true: and he is a
motion generative; that's infallible.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: You are pleasant, sir, and speak apace.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Why, what a ruthless thing is this in him, for
the rebellion of a codpiece to take away the life
of a man! Would the duke that is absent have done
this? Ere he would have hanged a man for the
getting a hundred bastards, he would have paid
for the nursing a thousand: he had some feeling
of the sport; he knew the service, and that instructed
him to mercy.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: I never heard the absent duke much detected for women;
he was not inclined that way.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: O, sir, you are deceived.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: 'Tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Who, not the duke? yes, your beggar of fifty;
and his use was to put a ducat in her clack-dish:
the duke had crotchets in him. He would be drunk too;
that let me inform you.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: You do him wrong, surely.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Sir, I was an inward of his. A shy fellow was
the duke: and I believe I know the cause of his
withdrawing.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: What, I prithee, might be the cause?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: No, pardon; 'tis a secret must be locked within
the teeth and the lips: but this I can let you
understand, the greater file of the subject held the
duke to be wise.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Wise! why, no question but he was.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: A very superficial, ignorant, unweighing fellow.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Either this is envy in you, folly, or mistaking:
the very stream of his life and the business he
hath helmed must upon a warranted need give him
a better proclamation. Let him be but testimonied
in his own bringings-forth, and he shall appear
to the envious a scholar, a statesman and a
soldier. Therefore you speak unskilfully; or if
your knowledge be more it is much darkened in your
malice.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Sir, I know him, and I love him.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Love talks with better knowledge, and knowledge with
dearer love.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Come, sir, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: I can hardly believe that, since you know not
what you speak. But, if ever the duke return, as
our prayers are he may, let me desire you to make
your answer before him. If it be honest you have
spoke, you have courage to maintain it: I am
bound to call upon you; and, I pray you, your name?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Sir, my name is Lucio; well known to the duke.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: He shall know you better, sir, if I may live to report
you.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: I fear you not.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: O, you hope the duke will return no more; or you
imagine me too unhurtful an opposite. But indeed
I can do you little harm; you'll forswear this again.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: I'll be hanged first: thou art deceived in me,
friar. But no more of this. Canst thou tell if Claudio
die to-morrow or no?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Why should he die, sir?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Why? For filling a bottle with a tun-dish. I
would the duke we talk of were returned again:
this ungenitured agent will unpeople the province
with continency; sparrows must not build in his
house-eaves, because they are lecherous. The duke
yet would have dark deeds darkly answered; he
would never bring them to light: would he were
returned! Marry, this Claudio is condemned for
untrussing. Farewell, good friar: I prithee, pray
for me. The duke, I say to thee again, would eat
