mutton on Fridays. He's now past it, yet ( and I
say to thee) he would mouth with a beggar, though
she smelt brown bread and garlic: say that I said so.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: No might nor greatness in mortality
Can censure scape; back-wounding calumny
The whitest virtue strikes. What king so strong
Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue?
But who comes here?
sp.stage: Enter ESCALUS, PROVOST, and Officers with MISTRESS OVERDONE.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Go; away with her to prison!

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: Good my lord, be good to me; your honour is accounted
a merciful man; good my lord.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit
in the same kind! This would make mercy swear and play
the tyrant.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: A bawd of eleven years' continuance, may it please
your honour.

sp.speaker: Overdone
sp.ab: My lord, this is one Lucio's information against
me. Mistress Kate Keepdown was with child by him
in the duke's time; he promised her marriage:
his child is a year and a quarter old, come Philip
and Jacob: I have kept it myself; and see how he goes
about to abuse me!

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: That fellow is a fellow of much license: let him
be called before us. Away with her to prison! Go
to; no more words.
Provost, my brother Angelo will not be altered;
Claudio must die to-morrow: let him be furnished
with divines, and have all charitable preparation.
If my brother wrought by my pity, it should not be so
with him.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: So please you, this friar hath been with him, and
advised him for the entertainment of death.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Good even, good father.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Bliss and goodness on you!

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Of whence are you?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Not of this country, though my chance is now
To use it for my time: I am a brother
Of gracious order, late come from the See
In special business from his holiness.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: What news abroad i' the world?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: None, but that there is so great a fever on
goodness, that the dissolution of it must cure
it: novelty is only in request; and it is as
dangerous to be aged in any kind of course, as
it is virtuous to be constant in any undertaking.
There is scarce truth enough alive to make
societies secure; but security enough to make
fellowships accurst: much upon this riddle runs
the wisdom of the world. This news is old enough,
yet it is every day's news. I pray you, sir, of what
disposition was the duke?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: One that, above all other strifes, contended
especially to know himself.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: What pleasure was he given to?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Rather rejoicing to see another merry, than merry
at any thing which professed to make him rejoice:
a gentlemen of all temperance. But leave we him
to his events, with a prayer they may prove
prosperous; and let me desire to know how you
find Claudio prepared. I am made to understand that
you have lent him visitation.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: He professes to have received no sinister measure
from his judge, but most willingly humbles himself
to the determination of justice: yet had he framed
to himself, by the instruction of his frailty,
many deceiving promises of life; which I by my
good leisure have discredited to him, and now is he
resolved to die.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: You have paid the heavens your function, and the
prisoner the very debt of your calling. I have
laboured for the poor gentleman to the extremest
shore of my modesty: but my brother-justice have
I found so severe, that he hath forced me to tell him
he is indeed Justice.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: If his own life answer the straitness of his
proceeding, it shall become him well; wherein if he
chance to fail, he hath sentenced himself.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: I am going to visit the prisoner. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Peace be with you!
sp.l: He who the sword of heaven will bear
Should be as holy as severe;
Pattern in himself to know,
Grace to stand, and virtue go;
More nor less to others paying
Than by self-offences weighing.
Shame to him whose cruel striking
Kills for faults of his own liking!
Twice treble shame on Angelo,
To weed my vice and let his grow!
O, what may man within him hide,
Though angel on the outward side!
How may likeness made in crimes,
Making practice on the times,
To draw with idle spiders' strings
Most ponderous and substantial things
Craft against vice I must apply:
With Angelo to-night shall lie
His old betrothed but despised;
So disguise shall, by the disguised,
Pay with falsehood false exacting,
And perform an old contracting. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 1
div.stage: The moated grange at ST. LUKE'S.
Enter MARIANA and a BOY. BOY sings.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: Take, O, take those lips away,
That so sweetly were forsworn;
And those eyes, the break of day,
Lights that do mislead the morn:
But my kisses bring again, bring again;
Seals of love, but sealed in vain, sealed in vain,

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Break off thy song, and haste thee quick away:
Here comes a man of comfort, whose advice
Hath often stilled my brawling discontent. Exit Boy. Enter DUKE disguised as before.
I cry you mercy, sir; and well could wish
You had not found me here so musical:

lg.l: Let me excuse me, and believe me so,
My mirth it much displeased, but pleased my woe.

sp.speaker: Vincentio

lg.l: 'Tis good; though music oft hath such a charm
To make bad good, and good provoke to harm.

sp.ab: I pray you, tell me, hath any body inquired for
me here to-day? much upon this time have I promised
here to meet.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.ab: You have not been inquired after: I have sat here all
day.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: I do constantly believe you. The time is come
even now. I shall crave your forbearance a little:
may be I will call upon you anon, for some advantage
to yourself.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: I am always bound to you. Exit

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Very well met, and well come.
What is the news from this good deputy?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: He hath a garden circummured with brick,
Whose western side is with a vineyard backed;
And to that vineyard is a planched gate,
That makes his opening with this bigger key:
This other doth command a little door
Which from the vineyard to the garden leads;
There have I made my promise
Upon the heavy middle of the night
To call upon him.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: But shall you on your knowledge find this way?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I have ta'en a due and wary note upon't:
With whispering and most guilty diligence,
In action all of precept, he did show me
The way twice o'er.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Are there no other tokens
Between you 'greed concerning her observance?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: No, none, but only a repair i' the dark;
And that I have possessed him my most stay
Can be but brief; for I have made him know
I have a servant comes with me along,
That stays upon me, whose persuasion is
I come about my brother.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: 'Tis well borne up.
I have not yet made known to Mariana
A word of this. What, ho! within! come forth! Re-enter MARIANA.
I pray you, be acquainted with this maid;
She comes to do you good.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I do desire the like.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Do you persuade yourself that I respect you?

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Good friar, I know you do, and have found it.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Take, then, this your companion by the hand,
Who hath a story ready for your ear.
I shall attend your leisure: but make haste;
The vaporous night approaches.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Will't please you walk aside? Exeunt Mariana and Isabella.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: O place and greatness! millions of false eyes
Are stuck upon thee: volumes of report
Run with these false and most contrarious quest
Upon thy doings: thousand escapes of wit
Make thee the father of their idle dream
And rack thee in their fancies. Re-enter MARIANA and ISABELLA. Welcome, how agreed?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: She'll take the enterprise upon her, father,
If you advise it.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: It is not my consent,
But my entreaty too.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Little have you to say
When you depart from him, but, soft and low,
“Remember now my brother.”

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Fear me not.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Nor, gentle daughter, fear you not at all.
He is your husband on a pre-contract:
To bring you thus together, 'tis no sin,
Sith that the justice of your title to him
Doth flourish the deceit. Come, let us go:
Our corn's to reap, for yet our tithe's to sow. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Come hither, sirrah. Can you cut off a man's head?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: If the man be a bachelor, sir, I can; but if he
be a married man, he's his wife's head, and I can
never cut off a woman's head.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Come, sir, leave me your snatches, and yield me
a direct answer. To-morrow morning are to die
Claudio and Barnardine. Here is in our prison a
common executioner, who in his office lacks a
helper: if you will take it on you to assist him,
it shall redeem you from your gyves; if not, you
shall have your full time of imprisonment and
your deliverance with an unpitied whipping, for you
have been a notorious bawd.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Sir, I have been an unlawful bawd time out of
mind; but yet I will be content to be a lawful
hangman. I would be glad to receive some instruction
from my fellow partner.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: What, ho! Abhorson! Where's Abhorson, there?

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Do you call, sir?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Sirrah, here's a fellow will help you to-morrow
in your execution. If you think it meet, compound
with him by the year, and let him abide here with
you; if not, use him for the present and dismiss
him. He cannot plead his estimation with you; he hath
been a bawd.

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: A bawd, sir? fie upon him! he will discredit our
mystery.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Go to, sir; you weigh equally; a feather will turn the
scale.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Pray, sir, by your good favour, — for surely, sir,
a good favour you have, but that you have a
hanging look, — do you call, sir, your occupation a
mystery?

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Ay, sir; a mystery.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Painting, sir, I have heard say, is a mystery;
and your whores, sir, being members of my
occupation, using painting, do prove my occupation
a mystery: but what mystery there should be in
hanging, if I should be hanged, I cannot imagine.

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Sir, it is a mystery.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Proof?

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Every true man's apparel fits your thief: if it
be too little for your thief, your true man thinks
it big enough; if it be too big for your thief,
your thief thinks it little enough: so every true
man's apparel fits your thief.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Are you agreed?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Sir, I will serve him; for I do find your hangman
is a more penitent trade than your bawd; he doth
oftener ask forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: You, sirrah, provide your block and your axe to-morrow
four o'clock.

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Come on, bawd; I will instruct thee in my trade;
follow.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: I do desire to learn, sir: and I hope, if you
have occasion to use me for your own turn, you
shall find me yare; for truly, sir, for your kindness
I owe you a good turn.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Call hither Barnardine and Claudio: Exeunt Pompey and Abhorson.
The one has my pity; not a jot the other,
Being a murderer, though he were my brother. Enter CLAUDIO.
Look, here's the warrant, Claudio, for thy death:
'Tis now dead midnight, and by eight to-morrow
Thou must be made immortal. Where's Barnardine?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: As fast locked up in sleep as guiltless labour
When it lies starkly in the traveller's bones:
He will not wake.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Who can do good on him?
Well, go, prepare yourself. Knocking within.
But, hark, what noise?
Heaven give your spirits comfort! Exit Claudio.
By and by.
I hope it is some pardon or reprieve
For the most gentle Claudio. Enter DUKE disguised as before. Welcome, father.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: The best and wholesomest spirits of the night
Envelope you, good Provost! Who called here of late?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: None, since the curfew rung.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Not Isabel?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: They will, then, ere't be long.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: What comfort is for Claudio?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: There's some in hope.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: It is a bitter deputy.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Not so, not so; his life is paralleled
Even with the stroke and line of his great justice:
He doth with holy abstinence subdue
That in himself which he spurs on his power
To qualify in others: were he mealed with that
Which he corrects, then were he tyrannous;
But this being so, he's just. Knocking within. Now are they come. Exit Provost.
This is a gentle provost: seldom when
The steeled gaoler is the friend of men. Knocking within.
How now! what noise? That spirit's possessed with haste
That wounds the unsisting postern with these strokes. Re-enter PROVOST.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: There he must stay until the officer
Arise to let him in: he is called up.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Have you no countermand for Claudio yet,
But he must die to-morrow?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: None, sir, none.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: As near the dawning, provost as it is,
You shall hear more ere morning.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Happily
You something know; yet I believe there comes
No countermand; no such example have we:
Besides, upon the very siege of justice
Lord Angelo hath to the public ear
Professed the contrary. Enter a MESSENGER. This is his lordship's man.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: And here comes Claudio's pardon.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.ab: My lord hath sent you this note; and by me this
further charge, that you swerve not from the
smallest article of it, neither in time, matter,
or other circumstance. Good morrow; for, as I take it,
it is almost day.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: I shall obey him.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: This is his pardon, purchased by such sin
For which the pardoner himself is in.
Hence hath offence his quick celerity,
When it is borne in high authority:
When vice makes mercy, mercy's so extended,
That for the fault's love is the offender friended.
Now, sir, what news?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: I told you. Lord Angelo, belike thinking me remiss
in mine office, awakens me with this unwonted
putting-on; methinks strangely, for he hath not used
it before.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Pray you, let's hear.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: “Whatsoever you may hear to the contrary, let
Claudio be executed by four of the clock; and in
the afternoon Barnardine: for my better satisfaction,
let me have Claudio's head sent me by five. Let
this be duly performed; with a thought that more
depends on it than we must yet deliver. Thus fail
not to do your office, as you will answer it at your
peril.”
What say you to this, sir?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: What is that Barnardine who is to be executed in the
afternoon?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: A Bohemian born, but here nursed up and bred; one that
is a prisoner nine years old.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: How came it that the absent duke had not either
delivered him to his liberty or executed him? I have
heard it was ever his manner to do so.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: His friends still wrought reprieves for him: and,
indeed, his fact, till now in the government of Lord
Angelo, came not to an undoubtful proof.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: It is now apparent?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Most manifest, and not denied by himself.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Hath he borne himself penitently in prison? how seems
he to be touched?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: A man that apprehends death no more dreadfully
but as a drunken sleep; careless, reckless, and
fearless of what's past, present, or to come;
insensible of mortality, and desperately mortal.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: He wants advice.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: He will hear none: he hath evermore had the
liberty of the prison; give him leave to escape
hence, he would not: drunk many times a day, if
not many days entirely drunk. We have very oft
awaked him, as if to carry him to execution, and
showed him a seeming warrant for it: it hath not moved
him at all.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: More of him anon. There is written in your brow,
provost, honesty and constancy: if I read it not
truly, my ancient skill beguiles me; but, in the
boldness of my cunning, I will lay myself in
hazard. Claudio, whom here you have warrant to
execute, is no greater forfeit to the law than
Angelo who hath sentenced him. To make you
understand this in a manifested effect, I crave
but four days' respite; for the which you are to do me
both a present and a dangerous courtesy.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Pray, sir, in what?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: In the delaying death.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Alack, how may I do it, having the hour limited,
and an express command, under penalty, to deliver
his head in the view of Angelo? I may make my case as
Claudio's, to cross this in the smallest.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: By the vow of mine order I warrant you, if my
instructions may be your guide. Let this Barnardine
be this morning executed, and his head borne to
Angelo.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Angelo hath seen them both, and will discover the
favour.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: O, death's a great disguiser; and you may add to
it. Shave the head, and tie the beard; and say
it was the desire of the penitent to be so bared
before his death: you know the course is common.
If any thing fall to you upon this more than
thanks and good fortune, by the saint whom I profess,
I will plead against it with my life.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: Pardon me, good father; it is against my oath.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Were you sworn to the duke, or to the deputy?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: To him, and to his substitutes.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: You will think you have made no offence, if the duke
avouch the justice of your dealing?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: But what likelihood is in that?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Not a resemblance, but a certainty. Yet since I
see you fearful, that neither my coat, integrity,
nor persuasion can with ease attempt you, I will
go further than I meant, to pluck all fears out
of you. Look you, sir, here is the hand and seal
of the duke: you know the character, I doubt not; and
the signet is not strange to you.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.ab: I know them both.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: The contents of this is the return of the duke:
you shall anon overread it at your pleasure;
where you shall find, within these two days he
will be here. This is a thing that Angelo knows
not; for he this very day receives letters of
strange tenor; perchance of the duke's death;
perchance entering into some monastery; but, by
chance, nothing of what is writ. Look, the
unfolding star calls up the shepherd. Put not
yourself into amazement how these things should
be: all difficulties are but easy when they are
known. Call your executioner, and off with
Barnardine's head: I will give him a present
shrift and advise him for a better place. Yet
you are amazed; but this shall absolutely resolve you.
Come away; it is almost clear dawn.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: I am as well acquainted here as I was in our
house of profession: one would think it were
Mistress Overdone's own house, for here be many
of her old customers. First here's young Master
Rash; he's in for a commodity of brown paper and
old ginger, ninescore and seventeen pounds; of
which he made five marks, ready money: marry,
then ginger was not much in request, for the old
women were all dead. Then is there here one Master
Caper, at the suit of Master Threepile the mercer,
for some four suits of peach-coloured satin,
which now peaches him a beggar. Then have we here
young Dizzy, and young Master Deep-vow, and Master
Copperspur, and Master Starve-lackey the rapier
and dagger man, and young Drop-heir that killed
lusty Pudding, and Master Forthlight the tilter,
and brave Master Shoe-tie the great traveller,
and wild Half-can that stabbed Pots, and, I think,
forty more; all great doers in our trade, and are now
“for the Lord's sake.”

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Sirrah, bring Barnardine hither.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Master Barnardine! you must rise and be hanged, Master
Barnardine!

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: What, ho, Barnardine!

sp.speaker: Barnadine
sp.ab: A pox o' your throats! Who makes that noise there?
What are you?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Your friends, sir; the hangman. You must be so good,
sir, to rise and be put to death.

sp.speaker: Barnadine
sp.ab: Away, you rogue, away! I am sleepy.

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Tell him he must awake, and that quickly too.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Pray, Master Barnardine, awake till you are executed,
and sleep afterwards.

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Go in to him, and fetch him out.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: He is coming, sir, he is coming; I hear his straw
rustle.

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Is the axe upon the block, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: Very ready, sir.

sp.speaker: Barnadine
sp.ab: How now, Abhorson? what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Truly, sir, I would desire you to clap into your
prayers; for, look you, the warrant's come.

sp.speaker: Barnadine
sp.ab: You rogue, I have been drinking all night; I am not
fitted for't.

sp.speaker: Pompey
sp.ab: O, the better, sir; for he that drinks all night,
and is hanged betimes in the morning, may sleep the
sounder all the next day.

sp.speaker: Abhorson
sp.ab: Look, you, sir; here comes your ghostly father: do we
jest now, think you?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Sir, induced by my charity, and hearing how
hastily you are to depart, I am come to advise you,
comfort you and pray with you.

sp.speaker: Barnadine
sp.ab: Friar, not I: I have been drinking hard all night,
and I will have more time to prepare me, or they
shall beat out my brains with billets: I will not
consent to die this day, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: O, sir, you must: and therefore I beseech you Look
forward on the journey you shall go.

sp.speaker: Barnadine
sp.ab: I swear I will not die to-day for any man's
persuasion.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: But hear you.

sp.speaker: Barnadine
sp.ab: Not a word: if you have any thing to say to me, come
to my ward; for thence will not I to-day.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Unfit to live or die: O gravel heart!
After him, fellows; bring him to the block. Exeunt Abhorson and Pompey. Enter PROVOST.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Now, sir, how do you find the prisoner?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: A creature unprepared, unmeet for death;
And to transport him in the mind he is
Were damnable.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Here in the prison, father,
There died this morning of a cruel fever
One Ragozine, a most notorious pirate,
A man of Claudio's years; his beard and head
Just of his colour. What if we do omit
This reprobate till he were well inclined;
And satisfy the deputy with the visage
Of Ragozine, more like to Claudio?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: O, 'tis an accident that heaven provides!
Dispatch it presently; the hour draws on
Prefixed by Angelo: see this be done,
And sent according to command; whiles I
Persuade this rude wretch willingly to die.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: This shall be done, good father, presently.
But Barnardine must die this afternoon:
And how shall we continue Claudio,
To save me from the danger that might come
If he were known alive?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Let this be done.
Put them in secret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio:
Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greeting
To yond generation, you shall find
Your safety manifested.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: I am your free dependent.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Quick, dispatch, and send the head to Angelo. Exit Provost.
Now will I write letters to Angelo, —
The provost, he shall bear them, — whose contents
Shall witness to him I am near at home,
And that, by great injunctions, I am bound
To enter publicly: him I'll desire
To meet me at the consecrated fount
A league below the city; and from thence,
By cold gradation and well-balanced form,
We shall proceed with Angelo. Re-enter PROVOST.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Here is the head; I'll carry it myself.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Convenient is it. Make a swift return;
For I would commune with you of such things
That want no ear but yours.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: I'll make all speed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Peace, ho, be here!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: The tongue of Isabel. She's come to know
If yet her brother's pardon be come hither:
But I will keep her ignorant of her good,
To make her heavenly comforts of despair,
When it is least expected. Enter ISABELLA.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Ho, by your leave!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Good morning to you, fair and gracious daughter.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: The better, given me by so holy a man.
Hath yet the deputy sent my brother's pardon?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: He hath released him, Isabel, from the world:
His head is off and sent to Angelo.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Nay, but it is not so.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: It is no other:
Show your wisdom, daughter, in your close patience.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, I will to him and pluck out his eyes!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: You shall not be admitted to his sight.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Unhappy Claudio! wretched Isabel!
Injurious world! most damned Angelo!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: This nor hurts him nor profits you a jot;
Forbear it therefore; give your cause to heaven.
Mark what I say, which you shall find
By every syllable a faithful verity:
The duke comes home to-morrow; nay, dry your eyes;
One of our covent, and his confessor,
Gives me this instance: already he hath carried
Notice to Escalus and Angelo,
Who do prepare to meet him at the gates,
There to give up their power. If you can, pace your wisdom
In that good path that I would wish it go,
And you shall have your bosom on this wretch,
Grace of the duke, revenges to your heart,
And general honour.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I am directed by you.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: This letter, then, to Friar Peter give;
'Tis that he sent me of the duke's return:
Say, by this token, I desire his company
At Mariana's house to-night. Her cause and yours
I'll perfect him withal, and he shall bring you
Before the duke, and to the head of Angelo
Accuse him home and home. For my poor self,
I am combined by a sacred vow
And shall be absent. Wend you with this letter:
Command these fretting waters from your eyes
With a light heart: trust not my holy order,
If I pervert your course. Who's here? Enter Lucio.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Good even. Friar, where's the provost?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Not within, sir.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: O pretty Isabella, I am pale at mine heart to
see thine eyes so red: thou must be patient. I
am fain to dine and sup with water and bran; I
dare not for my head fill my belly; one fruitful
meal would set me to't. But they say the duke
will be here to-morrow. By my troth, Isabel, I
loved thy brother: if the old fantastical duke of dark
corners had been at home, he had lived.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Sir, the duke is marvellous little beholding to your
reports; but the best is, he lives not in them.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Friar, thou knowest not the duke so well as I
do: he's a better woodman than thou takest him for.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Well, you'll answer this one day. Fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Nay, tarry; I'll go along with thee: I can tell thee
pretty tales of the duke.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: You have told me too many of him already, sir, if they
be true; if not true, none were enough.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: I was once before him for getting a wench with child.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Did you such a thing?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Yes, marry, did I: but I was fain to forswear
it; they would else have married me to the rotten
medlar.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Sir, your company is fairer than honest. Rest you
well.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: By my troth, I'll go with thee to the lane's end:
if bawdy talk offend you, we'll have very little
of it. Nay, friar, I am a kind of burr; I shall stick.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched other.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: In most uneven and distracted manner. His actions
show much like to madness: pray heaven his wisdom
be not tainted! And why meet him at the gates, and
redeliver our authorities there?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: I guess not.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: And why should we proclaim it in an hour before
his entering, that if any crave redress of
injustice, they should exhibit their petitions in the
street?

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: He shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch
of complaints, and to deliver us from devices
hereafter, which shall then have no power to stand
against us.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: Well, I beseech you, let it be proclaimed betimes
i' the morn; I'll call you at your house: give
notice to such men of sort and suit as are to meet
him.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: I shall, sir. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: Good night.
sp.l: This deed unshapes me quite, makes me unpregnant
And dull to all proceedings. A deflowered maid!
And by an eminent body that enforced
The law against it! But that her tender shame
Will not proclaim against her maiden loss,
How might she tongue me! Yet reason dares her no;
For my authority bears of a credent bulk,
That no particular scandal once can touch
But it confounds the breather. He should have lived,
Save that his riotous youth, with dangerous sense,
Might in the times to come have ta'en revenge,
By so receiving a dishonoured life
With ransom of such shame. Would yet he had lived!
Alack, when once our grace we have forgot,
Nothing goes right: we would, and we would not. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 5
div.stage: Enter DUKE in his own habit, and FRIAR PETER.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: These letters at fit time deliver me: Giving letters.
The provost knows our purpose and our plot.
The matter being afoot, keep your instruction,
And hold you ever to our special drift;
Though sometimes you do blench from this to that,
As cause doth minister. Go call at Flavio's house,
And tell him where I stay: give the like notice
To Valentinus, Rowland, and to Crassus,
And bid them bring the trumpets to the gate;
But send me Flavius first.

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: It shall be speeded well. Exit. Enter VARRIUS.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: I thank thee, Varrius; thou hast made good haste:
Come, we will walk. There's other of our friends
Will greet us here anon, my gentle Varrius. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: To speak so indirectly I am loath:
I would say the truth; but to accuse him so,
That is your part: yet I am advised to do it;
He says, to veil full purpose.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Be ruled by him.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Besides, he tells me that, if peradventure
He speak against me on the adverse side,
I should not think it strange; for 'tis a physic
That's bitter to sweet end.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: I would Friar Peter —

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, peace! the friar is come, Enter FRIAR PETER.

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Come, I have found you out a stand most fit,
Where you may have such vantage on the duke,
He shall not pass you. Twice have the trumpets sounded;
The generous and gravest citizens
Have hent the gates, and very near upon
The duke is entering: therefore, hence, away! Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: MARIANA veiled, ISABELLA, and FRIAR PETER, at their stand.
Enter DUKE, VARRIUS, LORDS, ANGELO, ESCALUS, LUCIO, PROVOST, OFFICERS, and CITIZENS, at several doors.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: My very worthy cousin, fairly met!
Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Angelo and Escalus
sp.l: Happy return be to your royal grace!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Many and hearty thankings to you both.
We have made inquiry of you; and we hear
Such goodness of your justice, that our soul
Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks,
Forerunning more requital.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: You make my bonds still greater.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: O, your desert speaks loud; and I should wrong it,
To lock it in the wards of covert bosom,
When it deserves, with characters of brass,
A forted residence 'gainst the tooth of time
And razure of oblivion. Give me your hand,
And let the subject see, to make them know
That outward courtesies would fain proclaim
Favours that keep within. Come, Escalus,
You must walk by us on our other hand;
And good supporters are you. FRIAR PETER and ISABELLA come forward.

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Now is your time: speak loud and kneel before him.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Justice, O royal duke! Vail your regard
Upon a wronged, I would fain have said, a maid!
O worthy prince, dishonour not your eye
By throwing it on any other object
Till you have heard me in my true complaint
And given me justice, justice, justice, justice!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Relate your wrongs; in what? by whom? be brief.
Here is Lord Angelo shall give you justice:
Reveal yourself to him.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O worthy duke,
You bid me seek redemption of the devil:
Hear me yourself; for that which I must speak
Must either punish me, not being believed,
Or wring redress from you. Hear me, O hear me, here!

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm:
She hath been a suitor to me for her brother
Cut off by course of justice, —

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: By course of justice!

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: And she will speak most bitterly and strange.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Most strange, but yet most truly, will I speak:
That Angelo's forsworn; is it not strange?
That Angelo's a murderer; is't not strange?
That Angelo is an adulterous thief,
An hypocrite, a virgin-violator;
Is it not strange and strange?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Nay, it is ten times strange.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: It is not truer he is Angelo
Than this is all as true as it is strange:
Nay, it is ten times true; for truth is truth
To the end of reckoning.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Away with her! Poor soul,
She speaks this in the infirmity of sense.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O prince, I conjure thee, as thou believest
There is another comfort than this world,
That thou neglect me not, with that opinion
That I am touched with madness! Make not impossible
That which but seems unlike: 'tis not impossible
But one, the wicked'st caitiff on the ground,
May seem as shy, as grave, as just, as absolute
As Angelo; even so may Angelo,
In all his dressings, characts, titles, forms,
Be an arch-villain; believe it, royal prince:
If he be less, he's nothing; but he's more,
Had I more name for badness.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: By mine honesty,
If she be mad, — as I believe no other, —
Her madness hath the oddest frame of sense,
Such a dependency of thing on thing,
As e'er I heard in madness.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O gracious duke,
Harp not on that, nor do not banish reason
For inequality; but let your reason serve
To make the truth appear where it seems hid,
And hide the false seems true.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Many that are not mad
Have, sure, more lack of reason. What would you say?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I am the sister of one Claudio,
Condemned upon the act of fornication
To lose his head; condemned by Angelo;
I, in probation of a sisterhood,
Was sent to by my brother; one Lucio
As then the messenger, —

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: That's I, and't like your grace;
I came to her from Claudio, and desired her
To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo
For her poor brother's pardon.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: That's he indeed.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: You were not bid to speak.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: No, my good lord;
Nor wished to hold my peace.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: I wish you now, then;
Pray you, take note of it: and when you have
A business for yourself, pray heaven you then
Be perfect.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: I warrant your honour.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: The warrant's for yourself; take heed to't.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: This gentleman told somewhat of my tale, —

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: It may be right; but you are i' the wrong
To speak before your time. Proceed.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I went
To this pernicious caitiff deputy, —

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: That's somewhat madly spoken.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Pardon it;
The phrase is to the matter.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Mended again. The matter; proceed.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: In brief, to set the needless process by,
How I persuaded, how I prayed, and kneeled,
How he refelled me, and how I replied, —
For this was of much length, — the vile conclusion
I now begin with grief and shame to utter:
He would not, but by gift of my chaste body
To his concupiscible intemperate lust,
Release my brother; and, after much debatement,
My sisterly remorse confutes mine honour,
And I did yield to him: but the next morn betimes,
His purpose surfeiting, he sends a warrant
For my poor brother's head.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: This is most likely!

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, that it were as like as it is true!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: By heaven, fond wretch, thou know'st not what thou speak'st,
Or else thou art suborned against his honour
In hateful practice. First, his integrity
Stands without blemish. Next, it imports no reason
That with such vehemency he should pursue
Faults proper to himself: if he had so offended
He would have weighed thy brother by himself
And not have cut him off. Some one hath set you on:
Confess the truth, and say by whose advice
Thou camest here to complain.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: And is this all?
Then, O you blessed ministers above,
Keep me in patience, and with ripened time
Unfold the evil which is here wrapped up
In countenance! Heaven shield your grace from woe,
As I, thus wronged, hence unbelieved go!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: I know you'ld fain be gone. An officer!
To prison with her! Shall we thus permit
A blasting and a scandalous breath to fall
On him so near us? This needs must be a practice.
Who knew of your intent and coming hither?

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: One that I would were here, Friar Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: A ghostly father, belike. Who knows that Lodowick?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: My lord, I know him; 'tis a meddling friar;
I do not like the man: had he been lay, my lord,
For certain words he spake against your grace
In your retirement, I had swinged him soundly.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Words against me! this' a good friar, belike!
And to set on this wretched woman here
Against our substitute! Let this friar be found.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: But yesternight, my lord, she and that friar,
I saw them at the prison: a saucy friar,
A very scurvy fellow.

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Blessed be your royal grace!
I have stood by, my lord, and I have heard
Your royal ear abused. First, hath this woman
Most wrongfully accused your substitute,
Who is as free from touch or soil with her
As she from one ungot.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: We did believe no less.
Know you that Friar Lodowick that she speaks of?

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: I know him for a man divine and holy;
Not scurvy, nor a temporary meddler,
As he's reported by this gentleman;
And, on my trust, a man that never yet
Did, as he vouches, misreport your grace.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: My lord, most villainously; believe it.

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Well, he in time may come to clear himself;
But at this instant he is sick, my lord,
Of a strange fever. Upon his mere request,
Being come to knowledge that there was complaint
Intended 'gainst Lord Angelo, came I hither,
To speak, as from his mouth, what he doth know
Is true and false; and what he with his oath
And all probation will make up full clear,
Whensoever he's convented. First, for this woman,
To justify this worthy nobleman,
So vulgarly and personally accused,
Her shall you hear disproved to her eyes,
Till she herself confess it.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Good friar, let's hear it. Isabella is carried off guarded; and Mariana comes forward.
Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo?
O heaven, the vanity of wretched fools!
Give us some seats. Come, cousin Angelo;
In this I'll be impartial; be you judge
Of your own cause. Is this the witness, friar?
First let her show her face, and after speak.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Pardon, my lord; I will not show my face
Until my husband bid me.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: What, are you married?

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.ab: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Are you a maid?

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.ab: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: A widow, then?

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.ab: Neither, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Why, you are nothing then: neither maid, widow, nor
wife?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: My lord, she may be a punk; for many of them are
neither maid, widow, nor wife.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Silence that fellow: I would he had some cause
To prattle for himself.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Well, my lord.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: My lord, I do confess I ne'er was married;
And I confess besides I am no maid:
I have known my husband; yet my husband
Knows not that ever he knew me.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: He was drunk then, my lord: it can be no better,

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so too!

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Well, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: This is no witness for Lord Angelo.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Now I come to't, my lord:
She that accuses him of fornication,
In selfsame manner doth accuse my husband,
And charges him, my lord, with such a time
When I'll depose I had him in mine arms
With all the effect of love.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: Charges she more than me?

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Not that I know.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: No? you say your husband.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Why, just, my lord, and that is Angelo,
Who thinks he knows that he ne'er knew my body,
But knows he thinks that he knows Isabel's.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: This is a strange abuse. Let's see thy face.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: My husband bids me; now I will unmask. Unveiling.
This is that face, thou cruel Angelo,
Which once thou sworest was worth the looking on;
This is the hand which, with a vowed contract,
Was fast belocked in thine; this is the body
That took away the match from Isabel,
And did supply thee at thy garden-house
In her imagined person.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Know you this woman?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Carnally, she says.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Sirrah, no more!

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Enough, my lord.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: My lord, I must confess I know this woman:
And five years since there was some speech of marriage
Betwixt myself and her; which was broke off
Partly for that her promised proportions
Came short of composition, but in chief
For that her reputation was disvalued
In levity: since which time of five years
I never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her,
Upon my faith and honour.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Noble prince,
As there comes light from heaven and words from breath,
As there is sense in truth and truth in virtue,
I am affianced this man's wife as strongly
As words could make up vows: and, my good lord,
But Tuesday night last gone in's garden-house
He knew me as a wife. As this is true,
Let me in safety raise me from my knees;
Or else forever be confixed here,
A marble monument!

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I did but smile till now:
Now, good my lord, give me the scope of justice;
My patience here is touched. I do perceive
These poor informal women are no more
But instruments of some more mightier member
That sets them on: let me have way, my lord,
To find this practice out.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Ay, with my heart;
And punish them to your height of pleasure
Thou foolish friar, and thou pernicious woman,
Compact with her that's gone, think'st thou thy oaths,
Though they would swear down each particular saint,
Were testimonies against his worth and credit
That's sealed in approbation? You, Lord Escalus,
Sit with my cousin; lend him your kind pains
To find out this abuse, whence 'tis derived.
There is another friar that set them on;
Let him be sent for.

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Would he were here, my lord! for he indeed
Hath set the women on to this complaint:
Your provost knows the place where he abides
And he may fetch him.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Go do it instantly. Exit Provost.
And you, my noble and well-warranted cousin,
Whom it concerns to hear this matter forth,
Do with your injuries as seems you best,
In any chastisement: I for a while will leave you;
But stir not you till you have well determined
Upon these slanderers.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: My lord, we'll do it throughly. Exit Duke.
sp.ab: Signior Lucio, did not you say you knew that Friar
Lodowick to be a dishonest person?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: “Cucullus non facit monachum:” honest in nothing
but in his clothes; and one that hath spoke most
villainous speeches of the duke.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: We shall entreat you to abide here till he come
and enforce them against him: we shall find this friar
a notable fellow.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: As any in Vienna, on my word.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Call that same Isabel here once again: I would
speak with her.
Pray you, my lord, give me leave to question; you
shall see how I'll handle her.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Not better than he, by her own report.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Say you?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Marry, sir, I think, if you handled her privately,
she would sooner confess: perchance, publicly, she'll
be ashamed.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: I will go darkly to work with her.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: That's the way; for women are light at midnight.
sp.stage: Re-enter OFFICERS with ISABELLA; and PROVOST with the DUKE in his friar's habit.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Come on, mistress: here's a gentlewoman denies all
that you have said.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: My lord, here comes the rascal I spoke of; here with
the provost.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: In very good time: speak not you to him till we call
upon you.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Mum.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Come, sir: did you set these women on to slander Lord
Angelo? they have confessed you did.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: How! know you where you are?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Respect to your great place! and let the devil
Be sometime honoured for his burning throne!
Where is the duke? 'tis he should hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: The duke's in us; and we will hear you speak:
Look you speak justly.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Boldly, at least. But, O, poor souls,
Come you to seek the lamb here of the fox?
Good night to your redress! Is the duke gone?
Then is your cause gone too. The duke's unjust,
Thus to retort your manifest appeal,
And put your trial in the villain's mouth
Which here you come to accuse.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: This is the rascal; this is he I spoke of.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: Why, thou unreverend and unhallowed friar,
Is't not enough thou hast suborned these women
To accuse this worthy man, but, in foul mouth
And in the witness of his proper ear,
To call him villain? and then to glance from him
To the duke himself, to tax him with injustice?
Take him hence; to the rack with him! We'll touse you
Joint by joint, but we will know his purpose.
What “unjust”!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Be not so hot; the duke
Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he
Dare rack his own: his subject am I not,
Nor here provincial. My business in this state
Made me a looker-on here in Vienna,
Where I have seen corruption boil and bubble
Till it o'errun the stew; laws for all faults,
But faults so countenanced, that the strong statutes
Stand like the forfeits in a barber's shop,
As much in mock as mark.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: Slander to the state!
Away with him to prison!

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: What can you vouch against him, Signior Lucio?
Is this the man that you did tell us of?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: 'Tis he, my lord. Come hither, goodman baldpate: do
you know me?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: I remember you, sir, by the sound of your voice:
I met you at the prison, in the absence of the duke.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: O, did you so? And do you remember what you said of
the duke?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Most notedly, sir.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Do you so, sir? And was the duke a fleshmonger,
a fool, and a coward, as you then reported him to be?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: You must, sir, change persons with me, ere you
make that my report: you, indeed. spoke so of him; and
much more, much worse.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: O thou damnable fellow! Did not I pluck thee by the
nose for thy speeches?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: I protest I love the duke as I love myself.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: Hark, how the villain would close now, after his
treasonable abuses!

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.ab: Such a fellow is not to be talked withal. Away
with him to prison! Where is the provost? Away
with him to prison! lay bolts enough upon him:
let him speak no more. Away with those giglots too,
and with the other confederate companion!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Stay, sir; stay awhile.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.ab: What, resists he? Help him, Lucio.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Come, sir; come, sir; come, sir; foh, sir! Why,
you bald-pated, lying rascal, you must be hooded,
must you? Show your knave's visage, with a pox
to you! show your sheep-biting face, and be hanged an
hour! Will't not off?
sp.stage: Pulls off the friar's hood, and discovers the Duke.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Thou art the first knave that e'er madest a duke.
First, provost, let me bail these gentle three. To Lucio
Sneak not away, sir; for the friar and you
Must have a word anon. Lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: This may prove worse than hanging.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: What you have spoke I pardon: sit you down:
We'll borrow place of him. To Angelo
Sir, by your leave.
Hast thou or word, or wit, or impudence,
That yet can do thee office? If thou hast,
Rely upon it till my tale be heard,
And hold no longer out.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: O my dread lord,
I should be guiltier than my guiltiness,
To think I can be undiscernible,
When I perceive your grace, like power divine,
Hath looked upon my passes. Then, good prince,
No longer session hold upon my shame,
But let my trial be mine own confession:
Immediate sentence then and sequent death
Is all the grace I beg.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Come hither, Mariana.
Say, wast thou e'er contracted to this woman?

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I was, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Go take her hence, and marry her instantly.
Do you the office, friar; which consummate,
Return him here again. Go with him, provost. Exeunt Angelo, Mariana, Friar Peter and Provost.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: My lord, I am more amazed at his dishonour
Than at the strangeness of it.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Come hither, Isabel.
Your friar is now your prince: as I was then
Advertising and holy to your business;
Not changing heart with habit, I am still
Attorneyed at your service.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: O, give me pardon,
That I, your vassal, have employed and pained
Your unknown sovereignty

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: You are pardoned, Isabel:
And now, dear maid, be you as free to us.
Your brother's death, I know, sits at your heart;
And you may marvel why I obscured myself,
labouring to save his life, and would not rather
Make rash remonstrance of my hidden power
Than let him so be lost. O most kind maid,
It was the swift celerity of his death,
Which I did think with slower foot came on,
That brained my purpose. But, peace be with him!
That life is better life, past fearing death,
Than that which lives to fear: make it your comfort,
So happy is your brother.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: I do, my lord. Re-enter ANGELO, MARIANA, FRIAR PETER, and PROVOST.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: For this new-married man approaching here,
Whose salt imagination yet hath wronged
Your well-defended honour, you must pardon
For Mariana's sake: but as he adjudged your brother, —
Being criminal, in double violation
Of sacred chastity and of promise-breach
Thereon dependent, for your brother's life, —
The very mercy of the law cries out
Most audible, even from his proper tongue,
“An Angelo for Claudio, death for death!
Haste still pays haste, and leisure answers leisure;
like doth quit like, and MEASURE still FOR MEASURE.
Then Angelo, thy fault's thus manifested;
Which, though thou wouldst deny, denies thee vantage.
We do condemn thee to the very block
Where Claudio stooped to death, and with like haste.
Away with him!

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: O my most gracious lord,
I hope you will not mock me with a husband.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: It is your husband mocked you with a husband.
Consenting to the safeguard of your honour,
I thought your marriage fit; else imputation,
For that he knew you, might reproach your life
And choke your good to come: for his possessions,
Although by confiscation they are ours,
We do instate and widow you with all,
To buy you a better husband.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: O my dear lord,
I crave no other, nor no better man.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Never crave him; we are definitive.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Gentle my liege, — Kneeling.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: You do but lose your labour.
Away with him to death! To Lucio Now, sir, to you.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: O my good lord! Sweet Isabel, take my part;
Lend me your knees, and all my life to come
I'll lend you all my life to do you service.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Against all sense you do importune her:
Should she kneel down in mercy of this fact.
Her brother's ghost his paved bed would break,
And take her hence in horror.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Isabel,
Sweet Isabel, do yet but kneel by me;
Hold up your hands, say nothing; I'll speak all.
They say, best men are moulded out of faults;
And, for the most, become much more the better
For being a little bad: so may my husband.
O Isabel, will you not lend a knee?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: He dies for Claudio's death.

sp.speaker: Isabella
sp.l: Most bounteous sir, Kneeling.
Look, if it please you, on this man condemned,
As if my brother lived: I partly think
A due sincerity governed his deeds,
Till he did look on me: since it is so,
Let him not die. My brother had but justice,
In that he did the thing for which he died:
For Angelo,
His act did not o'ertake his bad intent,
And must be buried but as an intent
That perished by the way: thoughts are no subjects;
Intents but merely thoughts.

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Merely, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Your suit's unprofitable; stand up, I say.
I have bethought me of another fault.
Provost, how came it Claudio was beheaded
At an unusual hour?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: It was commanded so.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Had you a special warrant for the deed?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: No, my good lord; it was by private message.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: For which I do discharge you of your office:
Give up your keys.

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: Pardon me, noble lord:
I thought it was a fault, but knew it not;
Yet did repent me, after more advice:
For testimony whereof, one in the prison,
That should by private order else have died,
I have reserved alive.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: His name is Barnardine.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: I would thou hadst done so by Claudio.
Go fetch him hither; let me look upon him. Exit Provost.

sp.speaker: Escalus
sp.l: I am sorry, one so learned and so wise
As you, Lord Angelo, have still appeared,
Should slip so grossly, both in the heat of blood,
And lack of tempered judgement afterward.

sp.speaker: Angelo
sp.l: I am sorry that such sorrow I procure:
And so deep sticks it in my penitent heart
That I crave death more willingly than mercy;
'Tis my deserving, and I do entreat it. Re-enter PROVOST, with BARNARDINE, CLAUDIO muffled, and JULIET.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Which is that Barnardine?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: This, my lord.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: There was a friar told me of this man.
Sirrah, thou art said to have a stubborn soul,
That apprehends no further than this world,
And squarest thy life according. Thou'rt condemned:
But, for those earthly faults, I quit them all;
And pray thee take this mercy to provide
For better times to come. Friar, advise him;
I leave him to your hand. What muffled fellow's that?

sp.speaker: Provost
sp.l: This is another prisoner that I saved,
Who should have died when Claudio lost his head;
As like almost to Claudio as himself. Unmuffles Claudio.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: If he be like your brother, for his sake
Is he pardoned; and for your lovely sake,
Give me your hand and say you will be mine,
He is my brother too: but fitter time for that.
By this Lord Angelo perceives he's safe;
Methinks I see a quickening in his eye.
Well, Angelo, your evil quits you well:
Look that you love your wife; her worth worth yours.
I find an apt remission in myself;
And yet here's one in place I cannot pardon. To Lucio
You, sirrah, that knew me for a fool, a coward,
One all of luxury, an ass, a madman;
Wherein have I so deserved of you,
That you extol me thus?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: 'Faith, my lord, I spoke it but according to the
trick. If you will hang me for it, you may; but
I had rather it would please you I might be whipped.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Whipped first, sir, and hanged after.
Proclaim it, provost, round about the city,
If any woman wronged by this lewd fellow,
As I have heard him swear himself there's one
Whom he begot with child, let her appear,
And he shall marry her: the nuptial finished,
Let him be whipped and hanged.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: I beseech your highness, do not marry me to a
whore. Your highness said even now, I made you
a duke: good my lord, do not recompense me in making
me a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Upon mine honour, thou shalt marry her.
Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithal
Remit thy other forfeits. Take him to prison;
And see our pleasure herein executed.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.ab: Marrying a punk, my lord, is pressing to death,
whipping, and hanging.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Slandering a prince deserves it.
sp.l: She, Claudio, that you wronged, look you restore.
Joy to you, Mariana! Love her, Angelo:
I have confessed her and I know her virtue.
Thanks, good friend Escalus, for thy much goodness:
There's more behind that is more gratulate.
Thanks, provost, for thy care and secrecy:
We shall employ thee in a worthier place.
Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you home
The head of Ragozine for Claudio's:
The offence pardons itself. Dear Isabel,
I have a motion much imports your good;
Whereto if you'll a willing ear incline,
What's mine is yours and what is yours is mine.
So, bring us to our palace; where we'll show
What's yet behind, that's meet you all should know. Exeunt.
